polls today for the crucial aposSuper Thursdayapos elections. Keir Starmer and Boris Johnson have been among those casting their ballots early on Thursday.They will cast ballots in local, national, Mayoral and Police and Crime Commissioner contests in Starmer ’s first real electoral test.The Labour Party leader will be hoping to make gains on councils, retain power in the Welsh Senedd and hold on to the stronghold of Hartlepool in a crunch parliamentary by-election.There is a lot at stake in Scotland, where the SNP are battling to achieve a majority in the Scottish Parliament - something Nicola Sturgeon believes will push Boris Johnson into agreeing to a second independence referendum.Meanwhile the Tories are hoping to hold on to metro mayoralties in the West Midlands and Teesside - and increase their share of Police and Crime Commissioners. Out on the campaign trail, Starmer said: “We’ve got to rebuild into the next general election – that is the task at hand.”For the latest on the local elections, follow our updates below :Dave BurkeVoters brave the weather to take part in the democratic processThe stakes are high on Super Thursday as voters in England, Scotland and Wales go to the polls.It is the first time people have had the chance to vote en masse since the start of the pandemic, with the results set to provide an indication how Labouraposs recovery is going under Keir Starmer.And in Scotland the results of the Parliamentary election could determine whether thereaposs another move toward indepence, with Nicola Sturgeon expected to force the issue with Whitehallher SNP does well. :Dave BurkeWhat war with France fishing dispute is about - and why its happened on election dayA tense stand off is taking place in waters around Jersey after two Royal Navy gunships were ordered to patrol a potential blockade by furious French fishermen.Boris Johnson sent two offshore patrol vessels to monitor the situation at the Channel Island on Wednesday night as a dispute erupted over post-Brexit fishing rights.On Thursday morning, dozens of French fishing boats gathered outside St Helier in protest at changes to fishing rules, prompting fears they might attempt to blockade the harbour.The timing of the row is pretty extraordinary as voters head to the polls for the first elections since .Dubbed Super Thursday, elections are being held for councillors, mayors and police and crime commissioners, as well as parliamentary elections in Wales and Scotland.The escalation in tensions over fishing in Jerseyaposs waters is a coincidence - and the Prime Minister is required to act in support of the Crown Dependency.Click here for the full story :Dave BurkeNuns have their say as Scotland goes to the pollsItaposs a big day north of the border, with a lot at stake in Scotlandaposs Parliamentary elections.These pictures show a group of five sisters from Carmelite Monastery in Dysart cast their vote at Dysart Community Hall, West Port, Dysart.Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is expected to lock horns with Downing Street over independenceher SNP party is successful.:Dave BurkeTory MP tweets wrong flag from  years ago to celebrate election dayA Tory MPaposs attempt to celebrate election day by waving a flag backfired when she used a -year-old version that doesnapost include Northern Ireland.Andrea Jenkyns shared the emblem on Twitter just after .am as polls prepared to open across England, Wales and Scotland.But instead of the current Union flag, she shared the flag of Great Britain - without Northern Ireland - that was used from the early s until the beginning of .The version is missing the diagonal cross of St Patrick of Ireland.Click here for the full story :Dave BurkeCouncil confirms church warder did oversleep ahead of polling station openingEarlier on today The Mirror reported that a baffled voter had to cast his vote in the back of a car because a church warder aposoversleptapos.Toby Porter said he cast his vote in Oxford at .am, and the normal polling station was up and running by .am.He said around a dozen people voted in the car before the centre at the Oxford Centre for Mission Studies was opened.We found it funny. Everyone was enjoying the novelty, he told the PA news agency.Now a spokesman for Oxford city council has explained what happened.He said: #xCThe keyholder overslept and for a short time at am electors were voting using the POs#xcars. This is standard procedure when a station building isn#xt open on time and part of the training we give them. The key is that ballot papers are ready to be issued at am, wherever that may be. The building was open within  minutes.#xD A spokesman for Oxford city council said: #xCThe keyholder overslept and for a short time at am electors were voting using the POs#xcars. This is standard procedure when a station building isn#xt open on time and part of the training we give them. The key is that ballot papers are ready to be issued at am, wherever that may be. The building was open within  minutes.#xD :Dave BurkeSome of our favourite dogs at polling stations so farPolitics often brings out the worst in people, so itaposs heartening that amid all the bickering one election day tradition is bringing people together.For the last few years it has been obligatory for dog owners to snap their pets outside polling stations, and today is no dferent.Here is a selection of our favourites.First time voting as a dog owner so obligatory #dogsatpollingstations pic. pic cavTarIJznmdash Daniel Dylan WrayMay ,  Fantastic turnout in Dulwich Village! #dogsatpollingstations #superthursday #londonmayor pic ytpUdjmdash Anna SkipwithMay ,  Taking your pooch to the polls  You know the drill, send us your pics! #DogsAtPollingStationsHere’s Max to show you how it’s done: pic jXJvqIvSmdash Dogs TrustMay ,  Tobin can#t vote, since he#s American. But he still believes in the importance of the democratic process #dogsatpollingstations pic qFYJYNqfMmdash Martin OrchardMay ,  :Dave BurkeVoters battle through snow to get to polling stations on crucial day in ScotlandSpare a thought for the people of Farr, close to Inverness, today.While it might be a bit chilly across most of the country, people there have to battle through more than most.Pictures show the village cloaked in snow on election day. Scottish Parliamentary elections could be crucial today, with parties urging as many people as possible to have their say.However because Covid will slow down counting, it could be  hours before people find out the result.:Dave BurkeNicola Sturgeon visits polling station in crucial election in ScotlandFirst Minister Nicola Sturgeon has met voters at a Glasgow polling station on the morning of what her party has dubbed one of Scotlandaposs most important elections.The SNP leader visited Annette Street Primary School in Govanhill - part of her Glasgow Southside constituency - along with Roza Salih, who is the lead SNP candidate on the Glasgow regional list.At the polling station, Ms Sturgeon and Ms Salih met three Syrian Scots who have lived in Scotland for eight years - -year-old Adnan Abdulbaki, and Iqbal Abdulbaki and Abdulruhman Abdulbaki, both  - as they prepared to cast their vote.Ms Sturgeon said it is great weaposve got everybody who lives here able to vote, saying it is an exciting and special thing to do, to which they agreed. :Dave BurkeSadiq Khan brings dog to polling station as he looks to continue as London mayorBringing dogs to polling stations is a long established tradition, and Sadiq Khan - who is seeking re-election as mayor of London - has joined in.The Labour candidate, who has led the city since , brought pet Luna with him as his we Saadiya cast her vote.Mr Khan has already voted by post. :Dave BurkePM issues rallying cry to votersPrime Minister Boris Johnson shared a video on Twitter encouraging people to go out and vote.It’s a very big day at the polls today. I hope everybody will go out and vote.Vote for the @Conservatives today. pic blembNNBmdash Boris JohnsonMay ,  :Dave BurkeScottish Labour leader casts votes as he calls on public to back partyThe leaders of Scotlandaposs political parties are heading to the polls to cast their own votes in the Scottish Parliament election.Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar voted at his local polling station at Pollokshields Burgh Hall in Glasgow on Thursday morning.Mr Sarwar is standing against First Minister Nicola Sturgeon in the Glasgow Southside constituency, which includes Pollokshields.Flanked by his we and four-year-old son, Mr Sarwar was in a buoyant mood, chatting with voters and answering questions from journalists.He said he used both votes for Scottish Labour and urged other voters to do the same. :Dave BurkeKeir Starmer casts his vote on crucial day for his leadershipLabour leader Keir Starmer has cast his vote today in a crucial day for his leadership.He and we Victoria were pictured outside the Greenwood Centre polling station in North London.He has called on voters to deliver a blow to Boris Johnson as he attempts to claw back from Labouraposs disastrous  General Election campaign. :Dave BurkeIts one rule for them, another for the rest of us says StarmerLabouraposs Keir Starmer has called on voters to punish the Tories for cronyism as they go to the polls today.He tweeted: From bending tax rules for those who have Boris Johnsonaposs phone number and handing out contracts to their mates to wasting your money on contracts that don#xt deliver. delivering the secure jobs, safer streets and health services we all want to see.They are the first step of Labouraposs plan to rebuild Britain, based on security and opportunities across the country. title: plans ramp up huge covid
story: NewsCovid vaccines could be cheaper for poor nations with patent change in pipelineThe US and EU could back waiving patent rights held by pharmaceutical giants, making it cheaper to produce jabs - but the UK has opposed the plans and pharma firms are worriedmirrorShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsA bishop receives a vaccine for Covid- at Juba Teaching Hospital in South Sudan " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticePlans to waive patent rights for coronavirus jabs to boost vaccines in poorer countries gathered pace today after Brussels signalled its backing. US Trade Representative Katherine Tai said that extraordinary times call for extraordinary measures and pledged to launch negotiations at the World Trade Organisation to try to secure the waiver. The EU is willing to discuss a proposal, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen revealed. The EU is also ready to discuss any proposals that addresses the crisis in an effective and pragmatic manner, she said in a speech to the European University Institute in Florence. Thataposs why we are ready to discuss how the US proposal for a waiver on intellectual property protections for Covid- vaccines could help achieve that objective.  The move piles pressure on Boris Johnson to offer Britainaposs support.South Africa and India made the initial vaccine waiver proposal at the World Trade Organization in October. The nations gathered support from a large number of developing countries who say it is a vital step to make vaccines more widely available. The World Health Organization said in April that of  million vaccines globally administered, only .% had been in low-income countries. Until now, the European Union has been with a group of countries, many of them home to large pharmaceutical companies, including Britain and Switzerland, that have opposed the waiver.

title: tory mp tweets wrongflag 400
story: NewsTory MP tweets wrong flag from  years ago to celebrate election dayAndrea Jenkyns bid at patriotism backfired as she hastily removed the flag - which stopped being used in  because it doesnt incorporate Northern IrelandmirrorShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsAndrea Jenkyns nod to patriotism went a bit wrong" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA Tory MPaposs attempt to celebrate election day by waving a flag backfired when she used a -year-old version that doesnapost include Northern Ireland.Andrea Jenkyns shared the emblem on Twitter just after .am as polls prepared to open across England, Wales and Scotland.But instead of the current Union flag, she shared the flag of Great Britain - without Northern Ireland - that was used from the early s until the beginning of . The version is missing the diagonal cross of St Patrick of Ireland.It is perhaps fitting, as tensions rise in Northern Ireland over trade issues in the Brexit deal - and as some accuse the Tory government of abandoning the region.But Brexiteer Ms Jenkyns insisted she wasnapost trying to make a political point.  Ms Jenkyns told the Mirror: It was an honest mistake, been up since the crack of dawn for elections, quickly tweeted, and later saw my mistake so deleted. Note to self, check and double check!! Given the amount of flag-waving Tory politicians have done recently - including putting them prominently in the background of TV interviews - Ms Jenkyns was roundly teased online. Twitter user Otto English said: Took Andrea Jenkyns MP a whole hour to remember what her own countryaposs flag looks like. They wrap themselves in it but they donapost know what it even is. Millions of Brits are voting on May  for  councils,  police commissioners,  mayors, two national parliaments, the London Assembly and the Hartlepool by-election. The ‘Super Thursday’ elections are far bigger than normal - because they include thousands of contests which were postponed from May  due to Covid.The bumper results will be the first ballot box test of Boris Johnson and Keir Starmer since the pandemic.

title: uk trade deal hopes revived
story: NewsUK-US trade deal hopes revived - but Joe Bidens envoy warns it will take timeA trade pact will be looked at but will take some time after hopes of a deal with Trumps White House collapsed, said US Secretary of State Antony BlinkenmirrorShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  MAY NewsBoris Johnson on a previous call to US President Joe Biden " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeJoe Bidenaposs top foreign envoy today boosted hopes of a US-UK trade deal. A transatlantic trade pact is a key goal of Boris Johnsonaposs post-Brexit plan to boost the economy. But efforts so far have stalled – and a bid for an agreement with Donald Trumpaposs White House flopped before he was ousted from office. Asked about a pact, Secretary of State Antony Blinken fuelled hopes a deal between America and Britain could be revived. He said: “I am, I was, hopefully very positive because there is no closer relationship.  And as we are grappling with problems, challenges, opportunities around the world, I find from my many conversations, many engagements with my counterpart Dominic Raab – also getting a chance to spend some time with the Prime Minister yesterday – that our two countries are profoundly in sync.And that makes a big dference.” Speaking following a meeting of G foreign ministers in London, he told the BBC: “As for a trade agreement, what we are doing now is our trade negotiator just got on the job, so sheaposs taking the time to go back and review everything that was discussed. Thataposs taking some time and we want to make sure that whether itaposs with the United Kingdom or with anyone , anything agreements we reach are consistent with the principles that President Biden has established, to focus on making sure that these agreements really advance the wellbeing of our workers and their families. Thataposs our focus.”  He added: “Certainly we are looking very carefully at whataposs already been discussed, whataposs already been done in these conversations, and we will carry it forward from there.”On Iran, Mr Blinken said the US had shown its seriousness and purpose in seeking to strike a new nuclear deal after Donald Trump tore up the internationally agreed Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action .However, he said Tehran had to show it was willing to comply with the terms of the agreement - intended to curb its ability to develop a nuclear weapon - amid concerns it was close to achieving a breakout capability. Compliance is compliance and what we donapost know is whether Iran is prepared to make the same decision and to move forward, he said.

title: voice mirror elections opportunity vote
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Elections an opportunity to vote for better future under LabourLabour mayors and councillors are delivering jobs, protecting local services and investing in their communities in contrast to the waste, cronyism and incomp­etence of Boris Johnson’s governmentmirrorShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  MAY NewsopinionYou have an opportunity to vote for a better future under Labour " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThursdayaposs elections could prove a pivotal moment in this country’s history. At stake is the future of the UK and the prosperity of millions of people. Across the land Labour has shown it is best placed to meet the challenges of our time. Andy Burnham has proved to be a proud and forceful champion of Greater Manchester. In the West Midlands, only Labour’s Liam Byrne has the vision required to bring jobs and investment to the region. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section London mayor Sadiq Khan has delivered on his promises to build more homes and create a greener capital, while in Wales First Minister Mark Drakeford deserves praise for his deft handling of the Covid crisis. It is Labour mayors and councillors who are delivering jobs, protecting local services and investing in their communities. This stands in contrast to the waste, cronyism and incomp­etence of Boris Johnson’s government. At the polling booth today you do not just have a chance to hold the Tories to account. You have an opportunity to vote for a better future under Labour. BBC pay a joke Graham Norton once said it was “pathetic” that the BBC had to reveal how much it paid its star presenters. Now we have an idea why he holds this view.  Accounts show he is getting more than £million a year to make his chat show. Perhaps Norton believes he’s value for money. More than three million pensioners aged over  may take a dferent view. They now have to pay for their TV licence as the BBC says it cannot afford it. The BBC needs to ask itself what is better value for money. Looking after its loyal audience or lavishing already well-rewarded stars with ever more lucrative contracts  Tots of fun

title: voter casts ballot car boot
story: NewsVoter casts ballot in car boot after church warden opening polling station oversleptToby Porter, from Oxford, shared a picture of the makesht polling station outside a church - which was reportedly locked when he turned up to cast his vote in the Local ElectionsmirrorShareByEmily ChudyDave BurkeNews reporter:,  MAY NewsVoter Toby Porter was surprised when he had to cast his ballot in the back of a car " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA baffled voter had to cast his ballot in a car boot this morning - after the church warden opening his polling station overslept apparently. Toby Porter said he cast his vote in Oxford at .am, and the normal polling station was up and running by .am. He said around a dozen people voted in the car before the centre at the Oxford Centre for Mission Studies was opened. We found it funny. Everyone was enjoying the novelty, he told the PA news agency. In a tweet which attracted more than , likes, he wrote: The church warden has overslept apparently so just cast my vote in a car. Click here for live updates on todayaposs local and nation elections Laura Lock, deputy chief executive of the Association of Electoral Administrators, said some polling stations in cars are seen at each election. All polling station staff are trained on how to set up temporary polling stations for cases just like this, she said. Unfortunately we do find key holders oversleeping, so every election we see a handful of polling stations in cars until access to the building can be sorted.People going to polling stations on Thursday are being encouraged to take their own pen or pencil and wear a face covering due to the coronavirus pandemic. Voters across England, Scotland and Wales are going to be polls today for the crucial aposSuper Thursdayapos elections.They will cast ballots in local, national, Mayoral and Police and Crime Commissioner contests in Keir Starmer ’s first real electoral test. The Labour Party leader will be hoping to gain signicant numbers of council seats and hold on to the former stronghold of Hartlepool in a crunch parliamentary by-election.

She explains: As scary as it may seem to talk about death and our end of le wishes, it’s infinitely preferable to leaving our loved ones wonderingthey made the right decisions.Below, weaposve listed  fascinating things British people have asked for at their own funerals in recent years.. I don’t see any similarities. title: bald men up two half
story: NewsBald men up to two-and-a-half times more likely to suffer severe Covid symptomsScientists say the male sex hormones called androgens - which cause hair loss - make them more susceptible to having the most severe symptoms of coronavirusmirrorShareCommentsByKelly-Ann MillsReporterMark Waghorn:,  MAY NewsBald men affected badly by covid " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeBald men are up to two-and-a-half times more likely to suffer severe Covid symptoms, according to the latest research. Scientists say the male sex hormones called androgens - that cause hair loss - make them more susceptible. It could explain the gender gap in deaths, with men twice as likely to succumb to the disease and the discovery could revolutionise treatment of patients and slash mortality rates.Men carrying mutations sensitive to androgens - which include testosterone - were found to be prone to worse coronavirus symptoms, researchers say.Scientists have also found similar results in women who are losing their hair due to androgens. A US team noticed  per cent of hospitalised patients had androgenetic alopecia - commonly known as male pattern baldness. This was dramatically disproportionate to the  to  percent in a similar age-matched population. The condition is caused by iants in a gene called AR, which regulates a protein known as TMPRSS - that is implicated in coronavirus. A study of  men hospitalised with the infection showed those with low CAG levels were at less risk of being admitted to the intensive care unit. Researchers say this could be a game-changer in combatting the pandemic. Lead author Dr Andy Goren, chief medical officer at Applied Biology, Inc, Irvine, Calornia, said: Our data show longer AR CAG scores are associated with more severe COVID- disease. The identication of a biomarker connected with the androgen receptor is another piece of evidence highlighting the important role of androgens in COVID- disease severity. The researchers also identied a promising therapy using a novel drug that blocks the androgen receptor. title: extra bank holiday september suggested
story: NewsExtra Bank Holiday in September suggested to give tourism and hospitality a boostTravel and hospitality bosses are urging the Government to add a new Bank Holiday after Monday proved a washout for many who had hoped to recoup losses after a dismal wintermirrorShareCommentsByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  MAY NewsThe May Day Bank Holiday was not the top earner the industry hoped for " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAn extra Bank Holiday in September could be on the cards to recoup lossestravel and hospitality bosses get their way. Industry chiefs are urging Downing Street to take action after the much-anticipated May Day break - the first holiday since Covid restrictions eased - was hit by heavy rain.For many businesses, it was the second Bank Holiday they had been able to welcome customers in over a year but the weather put many people off venturing out. Kate Nicholls, chief executive of UK Hospitality, wrote on Twitter : Hospitality and tourism has missed out on almost all bank holidays last year and the start of this.An extra bank holiday would be a boost to business, the economy, jobs and investment. Bernard Donoghue, head of the Association of Leading Visitor Attractions , said another Bank Holiday at the end of September could help the tourism industry repair our balance sheets.Do you think another Bank Holiday is needed in September  Let us know in the commentsHe also said it would be the ideal way to thank the NHS and key workers.He told The Independent : We know tourism was hit first, hit hardest and will take the longest to recover.A bank holiday weekend will typically generate  and  per cent of annual income. Losing so many has been really disastrous. To introduce a new Bank Holiday, the Queen - acting on advice of ministers - must make a Royal Proclamation.  This was most recently done in  to mark the Diamond Jubilee. Hundreds of pubs, bars and restaurants opted to close early on Monday due to the weather.It comes amid growing pressure on Boris Johnson to speed up the next stage of the roadmap, which would see people in England allowed inside pubs and restaurants from May .The last two Septembers, meanwhile, have seen a late surge of summer weather, giving industry bosses confidence their back-up plan wonapost also be hit with bad weather. Alastair Kerr, who spearheads the Campaign for Pubs, told MailOnline: We believe that the Government should have put in a contingency plan in place, to allow pubs to open up their inside areas instead, however it did not happen and as such many pubs remained closed on Monday.Pubs have faced the worst  months of trading in their history and as such missed many Bank Holiday trading days. Any opportunity to regain a Bank Holiday would be welcomed by many in the hospitality sector, as for many pubs, it is a well needed economic boost in quieter times.

title: holidaymakers face 10 hour delays
story: NewsHolidaymakers face -hour delays at Heathrow this year that are unavoidableThe Immigration Services Union has warned Brits they face  hour queues at UK airportsthey plan to go on holiday this year. Pressure is mounting on the Government to take action before May mirrorShareCommentsByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPassengers wait in the queue for check-in " %, rgba, rgba, url"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.Sign Up!When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeHolidaymakers are being warned they will face unavoidable -hour delays at UK airports for the rest of the year. Mammoth queues are already being caused at the London airport due to Covid-related checks as the UK battles to prevent mutant strains coming into the country. And this is before overseas travel gets the formal go-ahead from May  and the government releases its green list of safe countries. The Immigration Services Union , which represents Britainaposs border immigration and customs staff, is urging Downing Street to make drastic changes for when the ban on non-essential travel is lted. The union said delays of up to seven hours were seen when borders opened last summer, and fears they will be even worse this time and last for months. Stringent checks include all arrivals being spoken to by immigration officers to ensure they havenapost arrived through a red list country before they are allowed to pass through the e-gates. Any issues with paperwork can often take up to half an hour to put right, leading to swelling queues of disgruntled passengers.Have your holiday plans been affected by Covid  Let us know at webnews@mirror Lucy Moreton from the ISU told The i newspaper: We saw delays for seven or eight hours last summer, and with all the additional checks then we could see people waiting as long as  hours.Thereaposs no way around the delays at the border because Border Force officers will have to check the Covid status of all arrivals and that takes around  minutes per person. So, people from all over the world will be mixing inside for a long time. While British Airline Pilots AssociationGeneral Secretary Brian Strutton told MailOnline : Sorting border queues is absolutely in the Governmentaposs control, and they must do it now.As I explained at the recent Transport Select Committee hearing, the prospect of hours upon hours of queuing at airports is just another barrier that will put the public off travelling. We need passengers to feel confident, safe and secure when looking to travel this summer because without their bookings, the travel industry which is so important to the UK economy, is in serious trouble.  Simon McNamara, from the International Air Transport Association, told the i he is not optimistic the Government has a working plan for when borders open later this month. Heathrow, British Airways and Jet have already called on Home Secretary Priti Patel to increase border guard numbers to help alleviate the inhumane and completely avoidable queues already being seen.

title: how cope loss you live
story: AdvertorialHow to cope with loss when you live alone -  ideas to help you feel betterLosing a loved one is hard enough, but especially soyoure by yourselfmirrorShareByLaura Tait:,  APR AdvertorialNobody knows just how they will react after losing someone close to them. We will all be affected by grief at some point – something that has proved all too true for many people as a result of the pandemic. There is of course no “right” or “normal” way to grieve – everyone will experience their own emotional journey following a bereavement. We shouldn’t be putting pressure on ourselves to experience a certain sensation – like anger or acceptance – at a certain time, says Andy Langford, clinical director at Cruse Bereavement Care. Instead, we should be giving ourselves time and space.But it can be particularly hard when you live alone. The following advice from Co-op Funeralcare might help:Keep talking One thing that can give comfort is talking about your feelings with friends or family, so it’s important not to become isolated. Stay connected Use video and phone calls and social media to stay in touch. Arrange times to chat with people – having this in your diary can add something to look forward to and purpose to your day.  Stick to a routine As much as possible, try to get up at the same time each day, and prepare and eat meals when you normally would. If you can, get outside to exercise. Don’t be too ambitious Set yourself manageable tasks. Sometimes that will simply be getting out for a walk. Getting the balance right between being busy as a distraction and taking the time to focus on your grief is key. Look after your health Maintaining healthy habits for your physical wellbeing can help with your emotional welfare. As you focus on looking after yourself and practise self-care, remember that your GP will be able to offer advice on coping with bereavement

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeBritish navy and French police vessels patrolled waters around Jersey amid fears of a possible blockade as  French fishing boats gathered off the island like an invasion. A Jersey resident claims his boat was deliberately rammed by a French trawler in the harbour at St Helier as the row over post-Brexit fishing rights between the UK and France dramatically escalated on Thursday. A freight ship was initially trapped and unable to leave Channel islandaposs main port, but was later allowed to pass as a flotilla of French boats - backed by Brussels - crowded the harbour from about am. Angry French fishermen lot flares and waved banners calling for fishing access to the waters, with two local boats reportedly joining the demonstration as police and islanders watched the stand-off until the flotilla left at about pm following talks with Jersey ministers. The Royal Navyaposs HMS Severn and HMS Tamar, armed with machine guns and cannon, were positioned some distance away after being sent to the islandaposs main port to “monitor the situation” following mounting threats from Normandy trawlermen. France sent two police vessels to the area, including a former navy boat armed with cannon, as the situation in the British Crown dependency unfolded and a French fishing industry official warned weaposre ready for war. Prime Minister Boris Johnson reiterated his “unequivocal support” for Jersey during a phone call with island officials amid heightened tensions.Were you affected by the demonstration  Let us know at webnews@mirror. The Royal Navy vessels are set to remain in place as a precaution, Mr Johnson confirmed. Following the phone call, a Downing Street spokeswoman said: “The Prime Minister spoke to the Chief Minister of Jersey, Senator John Le Fondre, the Deputy Chief Minister, Lyndon Farnham and the Minister of External Affairs, Ian Gorst, this morning.“The Chief Minister updated the Prime Minister on the latest developments with French fishing vessels around Jersey’s coast.“The Prime Minister reiterated his unequivocal support for Jersey and confirmed that the two Royal Navy Offshore Patrol Vessels would remain in place to monitor the situation as a precautionary measure. “They agreed to stay in touch as the situation develops.” The row began after the island implemented new requirements under the terms of the UK-EU trade deal for boats to submit evidence of their past fishing activities in order to receive a licence to carry on operating in Jersey waters. French fisherman claim their rights are unfairly restricted. Earlier this week, David Sellam, head of the joint Normandy-Brittany sea authority, was quoted by French media as saying that Jersey had been taken over by an extremist fringe, who wanted to profit from Brexit.He added: Weaposre ready for war. We can bring Jersey to its kneesnecessary. Another skipper, Claude La Vaullée, said he and others had equipped their vessels to “re-stage the Battle of Trafalgar”. aposPatriotic dutyapos Jersey property developer Jonathan Ruff claims a French trawler deliberately rammed his boat as he went out to face the flotilla to stick up for the island and do his patriotic duty. Footage online showed two boats colliding in the harbour and witnesses shout oh following the sound of the impact. Mr Ruff told the Sun: I couldnapost believe what he was doing. He deliberately sped up and went straight for me clipping my bow. aposaposIf he had hit my engine I would have been in big, big trouble, I could have lost the boat and anything could have happened. aposaposThey were out of order andit wasnapost for some quick evasive action my boat could have been at the bottom of the Channel. Mr Gorst, Jersey’s External Affairs Minister, was among the local officials who took part in talks with the French fishermen amid the protest. He said the discussions were “positive”. He told BBC Radio aposs World at One programme: “It really is important that what has escalated over the course of the last three days, that we move away from that escalation and disproportionate threats, and start to deal with those detailed technical issues.  Earlier, Dimitri Rogoff, head of fisheries for the Normandy region, had told AFP the French boats would not try to block St Helier and wouldto France in the afternoon. The Commodore Goodwill freight ferry was initially unable to leave the harbour due to the flotilla crowding the harbour. Condor CEO Paul Luxon tweeted: Sadly she is trapped, we tried to bring her in earlier so in - discharge, load - out, and on her way, but in dialogue with Jersey Authorities ‘safety first’ of course.apos One of the trawlers positioned itself directly in front of the Commodore Goodwill, according to social media posts by Marie Carof-Gadel, a French journalist on board the trawler. The trawler later moved away and the delayed ferry left the port.The protest leader had instructed the vessels to let the ship leave, the Jersey Evening Post reported.  Two local boats from Jersey joined the protest, the report added. French fishermen were chatting via radio whether to push the protest further, but the consensus was no and they agreed to turn around and give the ferry room to leave the port, tweeted Paris-based Al Jazeera producer Tristan Redman, who was covering the scene in Jersey. The island sits  miles off the northern French coast and  miles south of Britainaposs shores. aposLike an invasionapos Jersey fisherman Josh Dearing described the scene at the port of St Helier on Thursday morning as “like an invasion”, with the French fleet mostly made up of “big French dredgers and trawlers” of  metres or more. Mr Dearing, , said: “There were probably about  boats. There were a few hand-held flares and smoke flares going off and apparently a few maybe bangers and stuff going off from the French.“It was quite a sight. It was impressive, I looked from the shore this morning and it was just like a sea of red lights and flares already going off at sea. It was like an invasion.” Originally from Kent, the owner of The Jersey Catch fishing company said the fleet was mostly made up of “big French dredgers and trawlers” of about  metres or more. There had been rumblings about a planned protest a few days ago, Mr Dearing said, but added that he had not been sureit was “serious or empty threats”. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  He said: “The French being the French, they don’t mess around. They can blockade their own harbours – they wouldn’t think twice about coming and doing it to us.” He was “absolutely” pleased to hear on Wednesday night that Royal Navy vessels were being deployed to patrol the waters around Jersey. He said: “We’re completely unprotected in Jersey. We’ve got nothing except for a few police officers. We don’t have a police boat, we don’t have a navy boat, we don’t have anything to protect us. “The French can be hostile. All of our livelihoods are in that harbour andthey wanted to they could cause damage.” Mr Dearing, who said his fishing licence costs about £,, said French fishermen who have not been granted a licence to fish had “thrown their toys out of the pram”.  He said: “Jersey fisheries has done nothing wrong. They’ve issued the permits to the French fisherman that were entitled to them and the ones that aren’t entitled don’t get the permits and that’s just le, that’s how it is. “The guys that have historical rights [to fish] have been granted them, as they should’ve done, and the ones that haven’t have just thrown their toys out of the pram.” Hugo Lehuby, a representative for the Normandy regional fishing committee which helped organise Thursdayaposs protest, said the French flotilla would not seek to impede access to Jersey ports, or stop local fishing vessels from operating. Speaking to Reuters by phone, he said the boats wouldto France in the afternoon, adding: The objective is to express our unhappiness about the restrictive measures that were imposed. This is not a blockade, he said. Itaposs not our objective to smash stuff up. Paris threatens to cut power Paris has warned it could cut off power to the island, which receives  per cent of its electricity from France through three undersea cables, in retaliation for the fallout. Franceaposs threats to cut off Jerseyaposs electricity were clearly unacceptable and disproportionate, the UK Government said. French fishermen launched their protest a day after Mr Johnson told Mr Le Fondre and Mr Gorst they have his unwavering support. French maritime minister Annick Girardin warned on Tuesday that the country was ready to take retaliatory measures, accusing Jersey of dragging its feet over issuing new licences to French boats.  The European Commission has said that the terms of the EU UK trade deal are not being met in waters off the coast of Jersey, due to the conditions imposed on licences for French fishing boats there. Speaking before Jersey officials held talks with the French fishermen, Mr Gorst told BBC News: “He and I will, as I say, later this morning be going out to listen to the French fishermen. “It’s really important that we are able to work with those fishermen to help them provide the necessary evidence so that,required, their licences can be amended. “As I’ve said, it’s important that we respond to threats, but the answer to this solution is to continue to talk and diplomacy.” Mr Gorst said the demonstration had been peaceful, “which is what we would have expected”. UK aposmust respond firmlyapos to threats He said it is “important” that the Government responds “firmly” to “threats”. On Wednesday Mr Gorst held talks with Marc Lefevre, the president of the La Manche region of northern France, on the dficult set of issues relating to fishing licences. As the protest continued on Thursday, he said: “We’ve heard disproportionate threats from Paris and now with a potential blockade, but the answer to the issues that are being faced are without doubt talking and diplomacy.” Askedit was disproportionate to send Royal Navy vessels to patrol the waters around Jersey, he said: “A minister in Paris threatened over technical issues on fishing licences to cut off Jersey’s electricity. “We have to take such threats seriously and respond appropriately.  “And fishing vessels threatened to blockade the main harbour into the island. “Again, we have to take that seriously and we’re extremely grateful to the Prime Minister for his full support and, as he said last night, those assets in Jersey waters are as a precautionary measure to monitor what’s happening in our waters and, as I’ve said, so far the protest has been peaceful, as we would expect.” Mr Gorst said the French have made clear their “frustration” over the new Brexit trade deal. He added: “But we are in a new era of relationship with the European Union. That is governed by the Brexit trade deal and we believe that it can serve our interest as well as the interests of French fishermen into the future. “We cannot look back to the previous arrangements. They have gone. We must make the new trade deal work in all of our interests.” Stephanie Yon-Courtin, a French MEP and member of the EU Fisheries Committee, called on Jersey residents and the UK Government to “understand that our fishermen need to carry on working”.  “This situation is all the more sad because historically Jersey and the French fisherman have always had very cordial and pretty good relations for the past decade,” she told BBC Radio ’s Today programme. “Some of Jersey’s people need to understand, and Jersey’s government and UK Government, have to understand that our fishermen need to carry on working. Askedshe supported the threat that power could be cut off to Jersey in the future, she added: “I’m just saying that at the last resort,we don’t have any other means to be understood, then we will have to consider that. “We don’t want to do that, I don’t think it’s good, I don’t think it’s good for anybody.” The European Commission said terms of the EU UK trade deal were not being met in waters off the coast of Jersey. European Commission spokeswoman Vivian Loonela told a Brussels briefing: “On April , the commission was notied by the UK authorities of granting  licences to the EU vessels who are fishing in Jersey territorial waters from May . “But there were additional conditions set to these licences. “We have, following the receiving of this, indicated to the UK that we see that the provisions of the EU UK Trade and Co-operation Agreement, that we recently agreed, have not been met there, have not being respected.” France sends police boats as tensions rise Royal Navy crew on board HMS Severn, previously used to shadow Russian navy warships off the English coast, and HMS Tamar watched Thursdayaposs demonstration from a considerable distance. The ships are used for fisheries protection and sailors are allowed to board other vessels for spot checks. Former British ambassador Craig Murray said he could “not believe how stupid, on every level, it is to send gunboats”. The former head of the marine section at the Foreign Office tweeted: I personally negotiated the UK fisheries agreement between France and the Channel Islands in, while Head of Maritime Section at the FCO. It was heated, esp in Cherbourg. A UK Ministry of Defence spokesman said earlier: HMS Severn and HMS Tamar are deploying to Jersey to conduct maritime security patrols. This is a strictly precautionary measure and has been agreed with the Jersey Government.  A Downing Street spokesman added: The Prime Minister and Chief Minister stressed the urgent need for a de-escalation in tensions and for dialogue between Jersey and France on fishing access. The Prime Minister underlined his unwavering support for Jersey. He said that any blockade would be completely unjustied. As a precautionary measure the UK will be sending two offshore patrol vessels to monitor the situation. They agreed the UK and Jersey Governments would continue to work closely on this issue. Athos, a French police vessel named after one of the Three Musketeers, was sent on a patrol mission just outside Jerseyaposs exclusive economic zone on Thursday morning. Athos was transferred to the National Gendarmerie in  after some two decades of service with the French Navy proper.A second French police patrol boat, called Themis, was also sent to the area. A French maritime gendarmerie spokesman said: ‘The Athos is carrying out a patrol mission in the area.  John Healey MP, Labour’s shadow defence secretary, said the threats on Jersey are completely unreasonable, as he urged the Government to meet with their French counterparts and the islandaposs authorities. He added: The Navy’s experience in sensitive situations will help reassure residents and protect Britain’s broader national interests. “The British Government must now get round the table with French colleagues and authorities in Jersey and sort this issue out.” Jersey fishermen aposnot very happyapos Don Thompson, president of Jersey Fishermen’s Association, said the “big question on everybody’s lips right now is whether the UK Government would give in to the tactics of the French. He told Good Morning Britain: “The French fishermen out there want conditions removed from their licences so that they can fish with no constraints in our waters, whilst our boats are subject to all sorts of conditions about how much they can catch, where they can go.” He said it would be “grossly unfair”the Government does “capitulate to that” and said such tactics might be used “again and again in the future”. He added: “They’re not very happy fishermen down here this morning, suspecting that we probably will see our Government give in to that.” Mr Thompson said Jersey’s fishermen had told the Government they are prepared to ditch their fishing licencesthe French win their demands.

title: kate middleton gives glimpse inside
story: NewsKate Middleton gives glimpse inside her new book day after Meghan Markle reveals hersIt comes amid accusations that her sister-in-law Meghan Markle was "trying to upstage" her after announcing her own book, titled The BenchmirrorShareCommentsByWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  MAY NewsThe project captured British le during the pandemic " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeKate Middleton has shared a glimpse into her photobook aposHold Stillapos ahead of its launch on Friday - a day after he sister-in-law unveiled her own childrenaposs book. The project, a collection of  photographs which captured le in the UK under lockdown and the Covid- pandemic, has been ongoing for a year. It will be released on May  and the Duchess of Cambridge has put out a video showing a brief glimpse into its contents via social media.The tease of the work came amid accusations that her sister-in-law Meghan Markle was trying to upstage her after announcing her own book, titled aposThe Bench.apos That book is said to be about the special relationship between a dad and a son. It is inspired by her husband Prince Harry and their son Archie, and will be published next month. On the Cambridgeaposs official Instagram account a video has been posted showing a number of pages from the book and some of the portraits that have been selected.The social media post is captioned with the words Coming this Friday...#HoldStill. The brief tease sparked a number of enthusiastic responses from fans who praised the Duchessaposs work.  One wrote: This was such a fantastic project. Congratulations to the Duchess of Cambridge for this awesome initiative. Another said: So excited to keep this for my son as he grows. Something for him to get a glimpse of the lives of normal people living through Covid. Thank you everyone who were involved. The Hold Still project was launched last year and invited people of all ages from across the UK to submit a photographic portrait which they had taken during the first lockdown.  From over , images submitted,  final portraits were selected and shown in a digital exhibition before being displayed across the UK. The book, named Hold Still: A Portrait of Our Nation in , will raise vital cash for mental health charity Mind and the National Portrait Gallery. Mum-of-three Kate wanted to create a lasting legacy of how the country has collectively and inidually battled through lockdown, celebrating the NHS and recognising how everyday people have coped during the pandemic.

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe Duke and Duchess of Cambridge took to social media to wish their nephew, Archie, a happy second birthday. Meghan Markle and Prince Harryaposs little boy is celebrating his special day in America, where the Sussexes have been living since quitting the royal family last year. To mark the day, Kate and William shared a photo taken at Archieaposs christening on Insagram and Twitter.The snap, taken by Chris Allerton, shows the Cambridges, Sussexes, Prince Charles, Camilla, Meghanaposs mum Doria and Princess Dianaaposs sisters. Prince Charles and Camilla also shared a snap to mark the day, but opted for a photo without Meghan. They reshared a picture that Harry and Meghan shared on Fatheraposs Day, showing Harry with his father and son at his christening. They wrote: Happy birthday to Archie, who turns two today. The Queen posted one of the photos taken at the photocall where Meghan and Harry introduced the world to Archie, in place of the traditional hospital steps photo. She wrote: Wishing Archie Mountbatten-Windsor a very happy nd birthday today. The birthday message comes after a dficult few months for brothers William and Harry and countless reports of tension between the couples. William was reportedly furious when his younger brother quit The Firm, with insiders saying he was only given about  minutes notice.  Things were made even worse by Meghan and Harryaposs interview with Oprah Winfrey, in which they made several shocking claims about the royal family. Harry said his brother was trapped in the institution while Meghan accused Kate of making her cry. Meghan also claimed she wasnapost able to get help for her mental health during her time in the royal family, despite having suicidal thoughts. She told Oprah she didnapost want to be alive anymore.

use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAn army of nannies, sleep consultants, therapists, yoga teachers and personal chefs - these are the luxuries enjoyed by Los Angelesapos rich and famous when they welcome a new baby. Thanks to their wealth and notoriety, Meghan Markle and Prince Harry will have a range of experts available to themneeded when their baby girl arrives and they juggle raising two young children and holding down careers. Given their multi-million pound deals with Netflix and Spoty, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex can afford to have a day nanny and a night nanny, and extra help from the likes of a maternal wellbeing therapist or a nutritionist, say parenting experts. Heavily-pregnant Meghan, , is due to give birth this summer, reportedly as soon as early June, and royal watchers expect she will lean on her mum Doria Ragland, , for help. The girl will join birthday boy Archie, who turns two today, and be the Sussexesapos second child since their wedding in . The American duchess gave birth to son Archie at the exclusive and private Portland hospital in London in May , and rumours have suggested she could opt for a home birth in the coupleaposs mansion in suburban Los Angeles this time. Ms Ragland, who spent time with the couple at Frogmore Cottage in Windsor after Archieaposs birth, lives close to the couple and is expected to provide similar support when her granddaughter is born. Harryaposs family is , miles away and he relies on video calls to keep in touch with the Queen and other family members who are still speaking to him amid a rt that was widened by the Sussexesapos bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey. Meghan is estranged from her father Thomas Markle Snr, who is orced from her mother, and her paternal half-siblings Thomas Markle Jnr and Samantha Markle. Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, William, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte, Louis, Archie and the rest of the family. Weaposll send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here. With limited family support, the Sussexes will have their hands full as they raise two children while running their documentary and podcast empire, and doing charity work. When Archie was born, reports claimed Meghan and Harry had just one nanny for him, but had tried out three in his first three months. Parenting experts said the Sussexes could turn to multiple nannies and other experts for help with their two children, especiallyMeghan doesnapost take a y period of maternity leave. Sophie Pickles, an early years teacher and parenting coach, told the Mirror: “Meghan and Harry may choose to hire a team of two or more nannies to help care for Archie and the new baby. “It is not uncommon for royals or the extremely wealthy to do so, often employing one nanny to stay in the house overnight to help with frequent night wakes and one or more to take care of the children during the day. “We know that when Archie was born, Meghan and Harry decided to hire a nanny to help them after initially saying they wouldnapost do so. “As for all of us, it sometimes takes until the baby is born for new parents to realise what a challenge it can be.” She added: “We already know that Harry and Meghan have stated that they do not want their home to be filled with staff, so it is unlikely that the new nanny will live with them. “All parents of multiple children know, however, that two is more challenging than one and with Archie about to hit the tumultuous age of two, they may well change their minds.”  It’s not known how much time self-employed Meghan and Harry will take from work off following the birth of their baby girl. As for how they could do things dferently this time, the couple could lean more on Ms Ragland and close friends. Ms Pickles said: “With Meghanaposs mum living close by, it is likely that she will be called upon to offer support and help, not only for Meghan as she recovers from birth but in caring for Archie while the family adjusts to having a new member. “After all, even when you have all the money in the world, there is nothing quite like the reassurance of leaving your baby in the arms of someone that you love and trust.” Royal biographer Angela Levin said itaposs possible the Sussexes will have more help around them after this birth, given they will have two children to take care of while running a business and doing charity work. The author of Harry: Conversations with the Prince told the Mirror: Meghan’s mother will want to help them and be involved, and the second one will be very close to her. I thinkwill rethink those early weeks . First-time mothers think they can do everything themselves. She might well have a night nanny and day nanny to help her, particularlyshe is working. You can’t juggle two in the same way that you can juggle one. I imagine a lot of money will come rolling in before she gives birth. They will be able to afford it.  Meghan and Harry, , are fortunate to have the kind of wealth and celebrity status that provide a gateway to experts and services most parents could never afford. The rich and famous in Los Angeles aren’t afraid to hire help or spend ridiculous amounts of money to get aposthe bestapos for their newborn.After her daughter Stormi Webster was born in February , reports claimed Kylie Jenner had four nannies.Kim Kardashian is said to have an “army” of nannies to help her care for the four children she had with Kanye West.Ms Pickles said: “While some of us can seek the services of sleep or lactation consultants for a one-off session, Meghan and Harry would be able to hire personal advisors to answer questions day and night. “They could take the form of an occupational therapist, paediatric doctors and physiotherapists, day and night nannies, a parent coach, a sleep consultant, a lactation consultant or a family counsellor - not to mention a personal trainer specialising in postpartum exercise, a nutritionist, a chef and a housekeeper.”  Lucy Shrimpton, founder of the Sleep Nanny, said Meghan and Harry could try to take on as much as they can on their own. She said: “Meghan and Harry are in a very privileged position that they have the means to pay for as much help as they could possibly need. “However, Meghan and Harry may want to do it as much as possible on their own. They seem like a very tight family, not afraid to get their hands dirty when it comes to all parenting responsibilities so they may try to be as self sufficient as possible.” Help from a sleep expert could set them up for long-term benefits such as the child’s development, and the familyaposs health and mental wellbeing. Ms Shrimpton added: “Being prepared with lots of rest before the baby arrives will be hugely beneficial for Meghan and Harry because the demands on parents of two will more than double. “Speaking from experience, where I went into labour already shattered with a -month-old, having plenty of time to rest beforehand will make a huge dference.  “Itaposs not as easy to catch up on sleep after having a baby when you have a toddler too. They may need to consider Archieaposs sleep and any adjustments to make to ensure he is not unsettled by the new sibling arriving into his world and demanding the attention of his parents.” Awena Naomie Ella, a matrescence specialist, motherhood wellbeing coach and occupational therapist, said Meghan could benefit from a specialist such as a maternal wellbeing therapist, who can help to set boundaries that allow for “rest, calm and connection”. She said: “Itaposs important to be aware of the hormonal, psychological, physiological, emotional, and spiritual changes a woman will move through. “Meghan’s wellbeing is the key to a safe and enjoyable entrance into this next phase of her and Harry’s le. “It is also important not to neglect or fail to acknowledge the emotional and wellbeing needs of Harry too. Ms Ella added: “Having access to a maternal wellbeing therapist or motherhood specialist, for example, can aid and support Meghan to embrace some simple and gentile wellbeing activates that fit into her current lestyle, and help her to prevent and manage any anxiety, possible onset of depression, overwhelm, and loss of sense of self that can sometimes come with early motherhood.

title: meghan markle sends coded message
story: NewsMeghan Markle sends coded message to royals in her new childrens book, says expertMeghan Markles book, The Bench, started off as a poem the Duchess of Sussex wrote for Prince Harry but shes now developed the idea into a moving storymirrorShareCommentsByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  MAY NewsIngrid believes that Meghan is sending a message to the royals " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice Meghan Markle is sending a coded message to the royal family about their decision to strip Prince Harry of his military titles in her new childrenaposs book, a royal author has claimed.The Duchess of Sussex announced earlier this week that she has written the new book, titled The Bench, which tells the story of fathers and their sons through a motheraposs eyes. Many fans have praised the book and thousands have already pre-ordered a copy. However Majesty magazineaposs Ingrid Seward believes that one of the pages shows the coupleaposs feelings towards Harry losing his royal military positions following Megxit. The beautul illustration shows a ginger hair dad dressed in Army unorm being reunited with his son, who he throws in the air, while the mum watches on through the window.  Writing for the Sun, Ingrid points out that this is something Archie has never seen, adding: Maybe Meghan is sending us a coded message that Harry has still not got over losing his military titles after the Queen stepped in.She also accuses Meghan of being hypocritical for writing a book about fatherhoods when she is still not speaking to her own. Her relationship with Thomas Markle has been dficult since the royal wedding but things were made worse when he gave a copy of her emotional handwritten letter to the Mail on Sunday.  Ingrid writes: Nor am I surprised at Meghan’s hypocrisy in writing a book about the joy of father and son bonding when the relationship between Harry and his own father Prince Charles has been brought to an all-time low by their Oprah interview. Meghan’s estranged dad, Thomas, lives roughly  miles away but she has not taken Harry or Archie to see him. I suspect Mr Markle believes they never will make that journey or repair the relationship.Royal author Phil Dampier agrees with Ingrid, telling The Sun : Meghan is probably showing how much the Army meant to Harry and how upset he is to lose his military titles.For Harry, who put his le on the line and then founded the highly successful Invictus Games for injured servicemen and women, losing the titles was the bitterest part of ‘Megxit.’  The Bench is being released through publisher Random House, and the cover features her royal title, The Duchess of Sussex. In a statement, Meghan said: The Bench started as a poem I wrote for my husband on Fatheraposs Day, the month after Archie was born,aposapos Meghan said in a statement. That poem became this story. My hope is that The Bench resonates with every family, no matter the makeup, as much as it does with mine.” It is narrated by award winning artist Christian Robinson Meghan, who is described as a mother, we, feminist and activist in the bio, will narrate the audiobook.

title: mum sets record fastest labour
story: NewsMum sets record for fastest labour by giving birth in loo in just  secondsAstonished Sophie Bugg, , from Basingstoke, Hampshire, said she had just thought she needed to do a number two - and less than a minute later she was leaving the bathroom with a new babymirrorShareCommentsByCharlotte Penketh-King:,  MAY NewsSophie Buggs daughter Millie was clearly eager to arrive into the world " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA mum gave birth in what may be one of the quickest times ever with just one push - and  seconds. Sophie Bugg, , was  weeks pregnant when she popped to the loo in the middle of the night - only to leave the bathroom with a baby less than a minute later. Her partner Chris, , had to act fast as Sophie appeared outside the bathroom door with the babyaposs head between her legs. With just one big push, baby Millie was born into her astonished dadaposs arms. Despite her extremely quick arrival, she is doing well with her family at their home in Basingstoke, Hampshire. Full time mum-of-three Sophie said: She was ridiculously fast! One moment Iaposm texting my friend on the toilet about needing a poo and seconds later, Iaposve got a baby in my arms. Actually pushing her out from when the lady on the phone told me to push only lasted  seconds, it was so fast. I had no pains and my waters hadnapost broken, there was no realisation I was having her at all. It sounds really crude but it just felt like I needed to go for a poo.Have you got a birth story  Email webnews@mirrorI had messaged my friend saying I donapost feel great, then put the phone down from where I was sat on the loo and went to get up from the toilet. As I went to lt myself up, my body just got that feeling like I needed to push for a poo. So I sat back down, pushed, and as soon as I did that push, I knew it was not from behind! I put my hand between my legs and her head was completely out. I shouted to my partner for help, went from the toilet to outside my toilet door on the top of the stairs, did one push and she was out! This isnapost the first time that Sophie has been taken by surprise by her speedy deliveries.  Back in , the mum went to the toilet in the middle of the night and ended up delivering her first baby, Paige, now eight, just  minutes later. Little Paige was born still in her sac, which is why Sophieaposs waters didnapost break, and a paramedic was able to pop the sac safely. Sophie was then booked in for an induction for her second child Lexie, now two, to ensure she was in hospital this time around. She gave birth to Lexie just  minutes after being induced.  She said: My first baby was quite an experience - you donapost expect anything like that with your first labour, to just be at home and then all of a sudden youaposve got a baby. You donapost know what to expect. You get told all these dferent things from people like youaposre going to have a show, youaposll have waters go, so youaposre waiting for these things to happen and they didnapost for me so I didnapost think I was giving birth until her head was out. My second baby, the doctors were so worried with the fact of how quickly I had my first that they had me induced so I was in hospital with my second, which was a relief. But then my third baby had the exact same plans as my first, but came even quicker! I couldnapost believe how quickly she arrived.  My body doesnapost give me the signs of labour. My midwe and my consultant told me that I go from zero to baby, I donapost dilate like every normal person does. Sophie had been booked in to be induced a whole week before Millie was born but the cheeky little girl decided she was ready to come even earlier. Two days before her planned induction, Sophie woke up in the early hours of the morning on March  with the urge to go to the toilet. She texted her friend to say she didnapost feel well and that she was going to go into the garden for some fresh air but her pal quickly warned her not to in case she gave birth.  But by the time her friendaposs advice came through on her phone, Sophie had already given birth to her newborn after pushing out her head instead of a aposnumber twoapos. She did one more big push outside the toilet door with her panicked partner Chris, who works as a storeman, in front of her - and baby Millie was born. Sophie said: I sat on the toilet, literally did a push and had the feeling that I should feel between my legs because it didnapost feel like a poo. I put my hand down and I just felt her head! It was four in the morning, it was just so unexpected. I was calling Chrisapos name as her head came out but so much energy was going into me giving birth, I felt like the lady off of Titanic, shouting aposhelpapos but it wasnapost coming out loud enough! I thought heaposs not going to wake up but then when I got off the toilet, he was stood there in the doorway so he must have heard me. I just looked at him and said aposyouaposve got to do the rest!apos His face dropped but then the phone came out, he was talking to the paramedics, it all happened so fast.  My two other kids both woke up in the commotion as well so I had my eight year old poking her head round her bedroom door asking aposMummy, are you ok apos Iaposm like aposyeah, Iaposm ok darling, just stay in your room for a minute!apos I went from sat on the toilet to outside my toilet door on the top of the stairs, did one push and she was out! I asked Chris afterwardshe was alright and he was like aposyeah, that was mad!apos Sophie remained on top of her stairs cradling her new born with the placenta still inside her for  minutes before a paramedic arrived. The umbilical cord was cut and Sophie and Millie were taken to hospital to be checked over but were released after a couple of hours in perfect health. Sophie said: I was shocked when I gave birth to my first so quickly but Iaposm just in disbelief that I ended up giving birth at home once again and even quicker! I had no pain relief with two of my kids and the after-pain with my third was terrible from where I was straining so much because I thought she was a poo. I was left so sore for weeks - I literally felt like a baboon!  I hear peopleaposs stories and I know several people who have been in labour for  hours and I canapost possibly imagine that! Iaposve never experienced that - my longest labour was  minutes and Iaposve had three children. I do feel sorry for these people who have to go through it!

title: queen never tells anyone what
story: NewsQueen never tells anyone what her favourite food actually is - for very clever reasonThe Queen has attended banquets around the world and tried a number of dferent cuisines, but when it comes to her favourite food, shes been keeping the exact dish under wraps for yearsmirrorShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThe Queen has eaten food all over the world " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeHer Majesty, the Queen, has eaten at a lot of fine establishments over the years, attending swanky banquets and having her own personal chef at the palace. As such, the -year-old is bound to have tried all sorts of cuisines and exotic specialities. Many people often wonder whether her own tastes and preferences are taken into account when travelling and eating abroad, but when it comes to her favourite food, there are few people who actually know what it is. And thereaposs a rather good reason why itaposs kept so secret.A royal insider has explained how the Queen doesnapost ulge her favourite food before travelling, so that she isnapost served the same thing everywhere she goes. As reported by The Express, Gordon Rayner, former royal correspondent for Thewho has covered more than  royal tours, said heaposd discovered this fact from a royal staff member.He said: As one of her staff told me, ‘If she said she had a favourite meal she would never get served anything .’ While some food choices might be kept under wraps, there are a few items she is known to love - including chocolate biscuit cake.Former Buckingham Palace chef, Darren McGrady, has spoken about the cake.

title: sainsburys takes down picture cream
story: :root Sainsburys takes down picture of cream tea that caused outrage in CornwallDisgusted Sainsburys customers in Truro, Cornwall complained about a photo of showing an "incorrectly" arranged cream tea that had clotted cream under a dollop of jamSainsburys takes down picture of cream tea that caused outrage in CornwallDisgusted Sainsburys customers in Truro, Cornwall complained about a photo of showing an "incorrectly" arranged cream tea that had clotted cream under a dollop of jamThis photo of a cream tea at a Sainsburys in Truro, Cornwall sparked outrageImage: SWNSBySam BeamishOllie Buckley:,  May Sainsburyaposs took down a picture of an incorrectly arranged cream tea after furious shoppers in Cornwall threatened to boycott the store. A photo of the sweet treat on a wall inside the store sparked a backlash from regulars in Truro. The image depicted a scone with cream spread on the bottom and a dollop of jam on the top. People in Cornwall have always put jam on first while folk in neighbouring Devon start with the clotted cream. Disgusted customers contacted Sainsburyaposs to complain, and as a result the supermarket chain apologised and quietly removed the photo from the baked goods aisle, CornwallLive reports. Who does a cream tea the proper way - Cornwall or Devon  Join the conversation in the comments section below. An empty frame now hangs on the wall where the picture was displayed. Sainsburyaposs said it had nothing more to say about the saga, which went viral. Earlier, Sainsburyaposs had said: Our afternoon tea has all scone wrong in Truro! We are reviewing the customer feedback we have received. Andreas Drosiadis, who took the original photo and runs the Mediterraneo deli in Truro, posted the image on Facebook asking: How did this happen   Andreas, , said: England is a country with strong local traditions that shape our everyday le. Jam first is a characteristic example of this and Sainsburyaposs should have known better. CornwallLive, a Mirror sister website, joined the furore, tweeting: Sainsburyaposs whataposs this  A fruit scone! with the cream on first! advertised in a Cornish store. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  The cheek of it! Do you think this is acceptable  Sainsburyaposs replied: An imposter! Which store did you see this please  Weaposll have a word with them about this blasphemy! After learning of the store location, Sainsburyaposs added: Thataposll never do at all Truro! Iaposve logged some feedback to the manager of the store to ensure they are made aware of this imposter and repair it accordingly.  Andreasapos tweet went viral and renewed the debate over how to dress a scone - is it jam first or clotted cream  Originally from Greece, the deli owner said: Because the clotted cream is denser than the jam, the jam should go first and the clotted cream after so everything stays neat and clean without the jam pouring on your fingers. He added: We now have the British authority on etiquette to back up the argument. Thataposs how the Queen has it. On Twitter user wrote: Sainsburyaposs are correct. When you have jam on toast do you put the butter on after the jam...  MORE ON...
