title: kate-promises-turn-pink-dress-four-year-old-mila
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.The Duchess of Cambridge in pinkThe Duchess of Cambridge has promised to wear a pink dress when she finally meets the youngster who became a symbol of the importance of isolation in Katersquos lockdown photography project.Kate chatted on the phone with four-year-old Mila Sneddon, who was pictured for the Hold Still initiative, kissing the kitchen window as her father Scott stood outside.Mila, who is undergoing chemotherapy for leukaemia, was separated from her father in the first lockdown for seven weeks, after he had to go to work and could not risk bringing coronavirus into the family home in Falkirk.The duchess admitted she was ldquonot wearing a princess costume right now when she was quizzed by the youngster on her outfit, but pledged to wear Milarsquos favourite colour when they eventually meet in person.Introducing lsquoShielding Milarsquo the first of a series of telephone calls that The Duchess held with participants from the Hold Still project.https:t.co weQpMajwmdash The Duke and Duchess of CambridgeMay , In a conversation posted on the Cambridgesrsquo new YouTube channel on Thursday, Mila asked Kate: ldquoDo you have a costume The duchess replied: ldquoIrsquom not wearing a princess costume right now, Irsquom afraid Mila. Do you have lots of dressing-up outfits yourself Mila said: ldquoYeah and told the duchess her favourite colour was pink.Kate added: ldquoOK, well I have to make sure I go and try and find myself a pink dress so that hopefully, when one day hopefully, Mila wersquoll get to meet, and then Irsquoll remember to wear my pink dress for you. Would that be nice The image of Mila and her father, taken by her mother Lynda, was entitled Shielding Mila, and was one of  pictures selected for the Hold Still photography initiative, launched by Kate and the National Portrait Gallery in .Coming this Fridayhellip##HoldStill @NPGLondon @coopuk pic VbOpfrZIQmdash The Duke and Duchess of CambridgeMay , People of all ages across the UK were invited to submit a photo which they had taken during lockdown, focusing on three themes ndash helpers and heroes, your new normal and acts of kindness.The call, recorded last autumn, was released to mark the publication of Katersquos new Hold Still photography book on Friday.Kate asked Mila about being apart from her father: ldquoHow come you couldnrsquot see him for so long Mila replied: ldquoBecause he had to look after me because I went for a treatment.The duchess asked: ldquoWas it really hard not seeing him Mila replied it was and told of the poignant moment they were reunited, saying: ldquoWhen he came into the house I was like, so surprised.The calls, which took place last autumn, saw The Duchess speak to a number of the  finalists who shared their experiences of le during the first COVID- lockdown in the UK by submitting an image to Hold Still. #HoldStillmdash The Duke and Duchess of CambridgeMay , The duchess told Mila: ldquoItrsquos a very small age to have a big operation. Were you very brave  You were a very strong girl, werenrsquot you Mila proudly said to Kate: ldquoI know all your kidsrsquo names.The duchess asked hershe could remember them, with the youngster listing Charlotte, then George and finally Louis.The duchess told her how Louis, who has just turned three, has been charging around on his scooter.ldquoLouis has got so big now. Hersquos very quick running around and hersquos on his little scooter as well. Hersquos very quick. I canrsquot keep up with him, Kate said.Mila began the call by saying: ldquoGood morning your royal highness. To which Kate replied: ldquoGood morning. Goodness me, yoursquore so polite Mila.The duchess also spoke to Milarsquos mother Lynda, describing how she and the rest of the judging  felt that the image was ldquosuch a powerful one. vw,vw,px, px"A mural in Manchester of one of the Hold Still photographs showing nurse Melanie Senior ldquoIt tells the story of this particular time and a very personal story to you, so thank you very for much for sharing it, Kate said.Mila is now five and currently in hospital, which Mrs Sneddon described to ITV as a ldquowee bump in the road.The youngster was also separated from her older sister Jodi during the first lockdown.ldquoIt must have been so challenging for all of you during lockdown, being separated, the duchess said to Mrs Sneddon.Mrs Sneddon said lockdown had had the surprise benefit of allowing them a period of time to focus on Milarsquos treatment without interruptions.She added: ldquoWersquove had our ups and downs. Scott and I are so proud of Mila and Jodi, my eldest, through this time and the challenges they have had to overcome.copy -. This site is part of Newsquests audited local newspaper network. title: engineers-biologists-join-forces-reveal-seals-evolved-swim
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.A grey seal pup on the beachResearchers have discovered how seals and sea lions evolved to swim.The findings could have potential implications for improving the design of man-made machines such as underwater drones and submersibles.Using cutting-edge engineering and animal behaviour, scientists have explained the origins of efficient swimming in the animals.Seals and sea lions are fast-swimming ocean predators that use their flippers to ldquofly through the water.But not all seals are the same ndash some use their front flippers to swim, while others propel themselves with their back feet.Fur seals and sea lions have wing-like front flippers specialised for swimming, while grey and harbour seals have stubby, clawed paws and swim with their feet.The reason behind these two dferent methods has long been a mystery to biologists, but now a new study led by Australiarsquos Monash University and including scientists from Londonrsquos Natural History Museumhas attempted to understand the evolution of these distinctive styles.Using computer simulations alongside footage of live seals, the team hoped to finally answer this mystery.Dr Travis Park, a researcher from the Natural History Museum who was involved in the study, said: ldquoOne of the key specimens used in this study was a female grey seal that was brought to the Natural History Museum after its remains were found in Margate.ldquoAlong with help from the Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital, who CT-scanned the animal for us, our scientists were able to turn this sad loss into a new understanding of how swimming in seals has evolved.The adult grey seal was found dead in Walpole Bay in Margate in  and was taken to the NHM for study.As well as analysing the animalrsquos limbs for the study, the team looked for parasites and investigated its stomach for a study into marine le ingestion of plastics.During the dissection, the team found a metal object in the sealrsquos head which they believed to be the cause of death. They reported the finding to the RSPCA.As well as real specimens, researchers used simulations to help understand how dferent seals propel themselves through the water.Lead author David Hocking, of Monash University, teamed up with engineer Dr Shibo Wang, from the universityrsquos department of mechanical and aerospace engineering, to use simulations to show how water flows around seal flippers of dferent shapes.Dr Hocking said: ldquoOur analysis showed that some Antarctic seals, like leopard seals, actually have very streamlined, wing-like forelimbs, despite being from the lsquofoot-propelledrsquo seal family.The discovery shows how wing-like flippers can evolve in seals that already swim with their back feet, providing a pathway for the evolution of forelimb swimming in the fur seals and sea lions.Dr Park added: ldquoWe found that grey seals still use their paws to hold their prey when processing it, but other seals like leopard seals have forgone this ability to maximise their swimming speed and agility, being able to capture more mobile prey.Researchers said that as well as explaining the origin of seals, this study may also improve human design.Dr Hocking said: ldquoSeals have had millions of years to perfect their swimming, and they can teach us a thing or two about underwater grace and elegance.ldquoLearning from them may help us to improve the design of human-built machines like underwater drones and submersibles, increasing their speed, manoeuvrability or energy efficiency.rsquondash The study is published in Current Biology.copy -. Everyone was enjoying the novelty, he told the PA news agency.A council spokesman said: ldquoThe keyholder overslept and for a short time at am electors were voting using the POrsquoscar.ldquoThis is standard procedure when a station building isnrsquot open on time and part of the training we give them.ldquoThe key is that ballot papers are ready to be issued at am, wherever that may be. The building was open within  minutes. vw,vw,px, px"Laura Lock, deputy chief executive of the Association of Electoral Administrators, said some polling stations in cars are seen at each election.ldquoAll polling station staff are trained on how to set up temporary polling stations for cases just like this, she said.ldquoUnfortunately we do find key holders oversleeping, so every election we see a handful of polling stations in cars until access to the building can be sorted.copy -. title: tourism analysis to begin next week in bid to move on from covid pandemic
story: An isles-wide assessment of tourism services is to begin next week, as businesses prepare to welcome visitors once again.Tour operator Island Vista has been selected by Shetland Tourism Association to carry out the analysis.The company already has close links with tourism providers.Businesses are expected to be contacted by Island Vista staff from Monday onwards.They will be asked to complete an initial online questionnaire, which will be followed up by a telephone interview.As well as providing an overview of available service provision, the work is also intended to provide a support mechanism for businesses.Those seeking guidance or support to re-open should be signposted to appropriate resources.STA chairwoman Emma Miller said: “This research will be extremely valuable to the industry as we look to recover from the prolonged restrictions imposed by Covid.#It’s important that we know what services Shetland has to offer, and that we identy gaps in provision or opportunities for the industry.#This is as much about helping businesses and making sure they have access to support as it is about gathering the data.#I’d encourage everyone who is contacted to engage with the project so we can work together to recover our industry and economy.”Jolene Garriock of Island Vista said: #As we all know, the pandemic has really knocked the tourism industry, both locally and the world over.#This is an important piece of work, which will not only help support the tourism industry as they work towards a successful restart but also to assure the local community that tourism businesses are taking all necessary precautions to restart safely and for the benefit of the community.#The team should be contacting businesses in groups throughout the coming months, so not all tourism businesses will hear from them immediately.Anyone who has recently opened a new tourism-related business is encouraged to send their contact details to Island Vista to ensure they are included...Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, title: polling stations open for scottish elections
story: Polling stations across Shetland opened at am this morningfor the Scottish parliamentary elections.Thirty-four polling stations will be open until pm tonight for physical votes, with six candidates standing for the Shetland constituency seat.Standing for the seat are: Beatrice Wishart , Tom Wills , Martin Kerr , Nick Tulloch , Brian Nugentand Peter Tait .The largest polling place is the Clickimin in Lerwick, for , voters, while the smallest is the Uyeasound Public Hall in Unst .The total electorate in the isles is , voters, with , already using a postal vote before today.Counting of the ballot papers will start at the Clickimin at .am on Friday, th May, with the final result expected at around pm...The SIC says it has taken steps to make polling stations as safe as possible as final preparations are made for Thursday#s Scottish elections. title: snp pledge 50000 island incentive as stark population projections are
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn its Scottish Parliament election manesto the SNP said the bonds will support people to buy homes, start businesses and otherwise make their lives for the long-term in these communities.The party have also pledged to give local authorities powers to manage the numbers of second homes in their area and work with Community Land Scotland to find land for more housing. from across the Highlands and Islands have signed an open letter seeking drastic action from local and national politicians amid an “existential crisis” caused by rising house prices, a dearth of sustainable work and an increase in holiday let properties.The SNP’s election manesto states: #To help stem depopulation, we will establish an Islands Bond # offering  bonds of up to £, to young people and families to stay or move to islands currently threatened by depopulation.#The bonds will support people to buy homes, start businesses and otherwise make their lives for the long-term in these communities.“It goes on to add: #To stop depopulation and support our communities, we will give local authorities the powers to manage the numbers of second homes in their area and we will work with Community Land Scotland so we can find the right land to deliver more housing in our rural areas.#Information on population estimates for  published by the Comhairle nan Eilean Siar highlighted a decrease of . per cent from mid  to mid  giving the Outer Hebrides an estimated population of ,.The median age in the islands was estimated to be . years in June  # which is more than seven years older than the average for Scotland as whole .Meanwhile, predictions from the National Records of Scotland suggest that the total population of the Outer Hebrides will fall to , by  # which represents a projected decline of  per cent or , people within that period.The equivalent figure for Scotland is projected to increase by . per cent.Moreover, in the period from  to  the Outer Hebrides it expected to see a . per cent decline in population, while the working age population #  years and over # is projected to decline by six percent.By contrast, it is projected to have a  per cent increase in those aged  and over by .While the chronic lack of affordable and available housing in many communities across the west Highlands and Islands has been a long-standing issue it has recently been placed front and centre of the political agenda ahead of Scottish Parliament Elections on th May.Indeed, across the last few weeks, the Free Press has reported on how young people are being acutely effected.The new movement Iomairt an Eilein has been spearheaded by nine campaigners originally from Skye, some of are currently based outwith the island having felt that they have been priced out of moving back home to work and live.Additionally, the Free Press has heard first-hand this week of the obstacles facing a young award-winning graduate seeking to move home to Lewis from Glasgow with his partner to live and develop his business.In terms of the outlook for the Highlands, the National Records of Scotland project the region’s population to increase by . per cent over the -year period between  and  from , to ,. However, the - age group is expected to drop by . per cent, while the - will experience an increase of . per cent.The corresponding figures for the decade between  and  highlight a drastic decline of . per cent in the  to  age group in the Highlands, while the  and over age group increased by . per cent.

title: tourism debate election hopefuls to take part in skye
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineThe focus will be on the recovery and development of tourism on Skye but any question that directly relates to issues affecting the island will be acceptable.The event, to be led by SkyeConnect chairman Dave Till, will allow people to submit questions in advance to the four candidates for the Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch constituency # John Erskine , Kate Forbes , Jamie Halcro Johnstonand Denis Rixson .During the -minute hustings candidates will be given two minutes each to make their pitch to voters. website. Questions can be submitted in advance to info@skye-connect

title: london developer wants to build 16 family homes on
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineCharles Garton Jones, a London-based property developer who also owns the Cow Shed boutique bunkhouse in Uig, is aiming to build the detached houses next to his Bracken Hide Hotel, off Struan Road. he hopes to provide the homes with an ultrafast broadband connection free of charge for the first five years.He said: “We have applied for  three-bedroom houses, and five four-bedroom houses. They are all on generous plots with good-sized gardens. The site is circa five acres, so we are looking at about three houses per acre.“The houses are entirely within the local plan site which is allocated for housing with an indicative housing capacity of  houses.”When asked what his motivation was for building, he said: “I think Skye post-pandemic is a good market for detached houses, but what we are trying to do is build homes with accessibility to schools and Portree itself.” sought to establish how much the homes would actually cost.Mr Garton Jones said: “We haven#t got that far. Simply because until you have planning permission you don’t have a product.“And the market moves, so a figure now could be out of date in six month’s time. I have been encouraged, though, by the new five per cent deposit mortgages the government are backing. I hope that could be really helpful.“Lenders are also starting to offer mortgages at five and a half times buyers’ earnings as opposed to four or four and a half times, so that will also help with how much people can borrow.”He added: “Because of the proximity to the schools and Portree it is not going to appeal to people who are looking to buy a holiday home. They want to be in the middle of nowhere.“I think it is going to appeal to people who are looking to buy it as their main home and want access to the schools and decent internet so they can work.”As an extra incentive the developer plans to connect all the houses via a full fibre GB broadband connection to the nearby BT exchange.“This connection will be provided by us completely free of charge for the first five years,” he added.“This is possible because the capacity we will have for the hotel is well beyond what we will need. This is still subject to BT surveys, though, but it is a realistic aspiration.”The housing scheme, which Mr Garton Jones describes as “an amalgam of Highland and Scandinavian culture” has been designed by Plockton-based architect Olli Blair, who caught the eye of the developer with his work on the Raasay Distillery building.Mr Garton Jones said he hoped to get on site by September October this year.The Bracken Hide Hotel is scheduled to open in April .If anyone is looking for more information on the homes or to register an interest they can contact Mr Garton Jones via charlie@gartonjones

title: waternish youngsters raise more than 7000 with
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoinePat Matheson from Halistra lost her husband Campbell to the illness, and her family thought it would be a good idea to raise funds for the charity in memory of Campbell and to raise awareness of AMMF. The family would like to extend their gratitude to everyone who helped achieve the remarkable sum in excess of £,.SomhairleRuairidhLexyAbigailRoganEoghainnMaraand Tobihad aimed to cycle a total of  miles to raise funds for AMMF. But on Saturday the th of March, which would have been their Seanair’s birthday, most of them cycled from Fairy Bridge to their Granny’s house and smashed their target – clocking up over  miles between them in high winds, rain, sleet and hailstones.

title: lifeboat mission leaves portree crew member in a
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineRNLI volunteers have been sharing some of the stranger situations they have found themselves in when their pagers go off to herald the lesaving charity’s Mayday Mile appeal.Iain Beaton, a member of Portree leboat, was enjoying that post-lockdown highlight, a trip to the hairdresser, when his pager sounded one day last summer.Iain, a builder who has  years’ leboat service in two separate stints, said: “I hadn’t had a haircut in months and I was desperately looking forward to it. I had not long sat down in the salon in Portree and was getting my hair washed when my pager went off.“I just sprinted out the door with the cape still on and my head full of shampoo – you don’t think when you get a shout, you just go. Morven the hairdresser didn’t know what had happened and I certainly got a lot of funny looks running down the pier!“We went to the aid of two women who had got cut off by the tide at the back of Raasay, and they kept looking at me. Needless to say I got endless ribbing from the crew. I’m just glad Morven hadn’t started cutting or I would have looked even stranger. Morven came up to the house the next day so I did eventually get that haircut.”The RNLI is preparing for a busy summer with more families than ever expected to opt for holidays in the UK because of the pandemic. Many of them will be heading to the coast.To keep lesavers kitted out and trained it has launched the Mayday Mile which encourages folk to cover a one-mile distance, be it walking, running, swimming, skating or cycling, to help raise funds. and find out how to make a donation or hold a socially-distanced sponsored event.

title: editorial kennedy commitment would be a fitting cause for political
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIt was his seventh in a row as a Highland member of parliament and with a majority of more than , in Ross, Skye and Lochaber it seemed then that his seat was secure for as long as he wanted it.Yeta week is a long time in politics, the last decade has proved aeonic.The General Election of May  brought an end to the UK’s  years of centre-left dominance, and it was to prove the first in a series of seismic polls which tore up the psephologist’s rule book.The  election gave the Liberal Democrats a taste of power in an unlikely coalition with the Tories, but it has been electoral oblivion for them ever since – including in their former Highland heartlands.A year later the SNP romped to a majority in a Scottish parliament that had been designed to prevent any one party having overall control. In so doing the path was paved toward an independence referendum which eventually maintained the -year-old Union, but still served to elevate the question to become the defining Scottish issue of our times.– was Charles Kennedy’s.A few weeks later the affable Abrach was dead, aged just .The turbulent, and increasingly polarised times continued as a Brexit referendum was granted, and the UK – in spite of all major parties backing remain – voted to leave the EU in . There followed four years of painful negotiation Theresa May was anointed, became a lame duck, and departed as PM to be replaced by Boris Johnson.Johnson saw off Jeremy Corbyn and ‘got Brexit done’ as he said he would, but post-Covid he might yet be done for himself. As rumours rage that in preference to lockdown he said he would tolerate a virus # from which he almost died # spreading so severely that bodies could “pile high on the streets”, there is a growing sense that the public reckoning he has long escaped may finally be in sight.Meanwhile in Scotland, having survived the ugly fall-out from of an investigation into the handling of sexual harassment complaints against her predecessor and political mentor Alex Salmond, Nicola Sturgeon remains odds-on to become First Minister again in  # perhaps even with the overall majority she was unable to secure in .Whether victory leads to a second referendum depends not only on next week’s result but on whose ‘rights’ will take precedence in the eyes of the UK government who by law would need to sanction another vote.Because inescapably it is Covid-, how it is tackled and treated, and how we can recover as a country from it, that is the major issue facing all of us.It seems lamentable that, amid the constitutional flux and an increasing entrenchment of views, that there has been so little sign of a consensual approach – between both governments and parties # to steer the country away from the crisis.And that brings us back to the original point about the late Charles Kennedy.The landscape which he occupied has altered beyond recognition, but has changed politics meant better politics or brought improved outcomes  The jury is out, and it is a question voters should consider as they head for the booths.’ brought some encouraging news.Having seen the treatment Mr Kennedy received back in , the LibDems have called for a “a zero-tolerance approach to abuse and to lead a respectful campaign”.Their pledge calls for derogatory, untrue, or hateful messages on social media to be publicly denounced and challenged to treat political opponents and journalists with respect, and to run an honest campaign.The SNP, Tories, Labour and Greens – all of whom have members who have experienced threats and abuse in ious forms – have all signed up.It would be a fitting tribute to Charles Kennedythis is one electoral promise they can work together and fulfil.

title: highland locations connect to 4g for the first time thanks to
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na Daoine: EEPartnering with the Scottish Government, the Home Office and WHP Telecoms, EE has connected locations, including Tarskavaigand Glencripesdale to its high-speed G network, with Killilanand Polbaindue to be connected this summer.These sites are part of the Scottish Government’s £ million Scottish G Infill programmewhich is anticipated to deliver up to  masts to so-called ‘not spots’ in rural Scotland – including those being used by EE as part of the Emergency Services Network roll-out.Along with these sites, EE will extend G in a further  areas across the country, including to Dalwhinnie and Nairn, by the end of  as part of the Shared Rural Network Initiative, boosting connectivity in rural Scotland. The programme is run by the UK’s four mobile network operators and the UK Government to extend G coverage to % of the UK’s geography by the middle of this decade.Jane Wood, BT Group Scotland director, said: “Extending the network will offer a much-needed leline to families and businesses impacted by the ongoing pandemic, as many are working from home and keeping in touch with family and friends via digital technology.”Martyn Cheyne, WHP strategic development director, said: “WHP Telecoms is pleased to have facilitated this reliable coverage by providing robust, future-proofed infrastructure from which EE is now delivering G coverage. We welcome other operators to share this site to reduce the amount of infrastructure required in the landscape, increasing coverage and choice for everyone.”

title: man struck with baseball bat in balymena house invasion
story: Detectives in Ballymena area appealing for witnesses and information in relation to an aggravated burglary which took place yesterdayevening.Detective Sergeant Lenaghan said: “A report was received that at approximately pm, two men forced their way into a house at Princes Street in the town and assaulted the male occupant.“It was reported that one of the men punched the occupant in the face, and the second man struck him on the body with a silver coloured baseball bat. The occupant received medical attention for his injuries but fortunately did not have to be taken to hospital.“Damage was also caused to a TV during the incident.“One of the men is described as being approximately  ft ” to  ft ” tall, around  years of age, of stocky build and clean shaven. He was dressed in a dark coloured baseball cap and an Adidas tracksuit.“The second male is described as being approximately  ft ” to  ft  “ tall, around  or  years of age, and of slim build. He had dirty fair hair which appeared to be shaved at the sides and back, and was dressed in a dark red zipped hoody and grey tracksuit bottoms.“Both men were reported to speak with local accents.“Enquiries are continuing to establish the circumstances surrounding the incident and we would appeal to anyone who witnessed anything suspicious in the area to contact detectives on  quoting reference number  of   .”A report can also be made using the online reporting form via www.psni.police.uk makeareport. Alternatively, information can be provided to Crimestoppers anonymously on    or online at www.crimestoppers-uk.org

title: cases of india variant confirmed in ni
story: The Department of Health has been notied by the Public Health Agency of seven confirmed cases of the VUI B...Coronavirus iant in Northern Ireland.These are the first confirmed cases of this iant in the province.The Department of Health is working closely with the PHA and the Regional Virology Laboratory in relation to the investigation and assessment of these cases.Incident management protocols have been activated. A detailed health protection risk assessment will be part of the public health response, as will contact tracing.Chief Medical Officer Dr Michael McBride said: “This news is not entirely unexpected and plans are in place for such an eventuality.“While preventative measures – including travel restrictions – are very important, the assessment is that these will delay rather than permanently prevent the spread of iants already detected where on these islands.“Confirmation of these cases does not mean this iant is going to become the most prevalent or the dominant strain in Northern Ireland.“It does, however, highlight why caution is still essential in relation to COVID-.“The most effective way to stop iants developing or spreading is to keep pushing down infection rates and transmission of the virus in our community.“All iants spread in the same way. We protect ourselves and others by following public health advice and getting vaccinated when our turn comes.“Social distancing and limiting the number of contacts we have are still vitally important. So too are wearing a face covering and washing hands well and often. Also, please always remember the particular risks from indoor settings, especially those that are crowded and have poor ventilation.”

title: fenaghy road surface scheme ready to start
story: A pound, resurfacing scheme for Fenaghy Road, Cullybackey will commence on Monday  May .The scheme extends from Main Street Cullybackey for approximately . kilometres to Galgorm Spa and Resort and is expected to be completed by Friday  June .To facilitate the works it will be necessary to introduce a full road closure on Fenaghy Road, Monday to Friday from .am to .pm for the duration of the works and also on Sunday  May. During these times a ersion will be in operation via Sand Road Woodtown Road Ballymena Road and vice versa.The Department has programmed the work operations and traffic management arrangements to minimise inconvenience, however, road users should expect some delays and are advised to allow additional time when travelling in the area.In order to help ensure the safety of road users and road workers the public is asked to comply with all temporary traffic restrictions and to drive with extra care when travelling in the vicinity of the works.The dates and duration of the works will be dependent on the progress of the scheme and on favourable weather conditions. All work will be carried out in line with current public health and safety advice with safe systems of working in place for staff and contractors.For more information about this and other improvement schemes visit: www.TrafficwatchNIMinister Mallon said:“This signicant investment will greatly improve the strength and surface quality of this section of the road network. This will benefit all who use it including businesses and residents in the area. I would like to thank the travelling public and local residents in advance for their cooperation while these much needed works are completed.”

title: seth raises 1340 for great cause
story: A Ballymena teenager has raised more than pound for Macmillan Cancer Support after completing a half marathon at the weekend. Seth Parkis a Year  pupil at Ballymena Academy and is keen on rugby, football, golf and hockey.During lockdown he decided to keep himself fit by training for the Belfast half marathon. For  weeks Seth was pounding the roads to build his fitness and all that hard training paid idends at the weekend when he completed his run.He originally set out to raise poundbut his efforts save seen him race past that target with the current total sitting at at pound!You can help raise money for this great cause by donating directly to the fundraising page www.justgiving Seth-Park.JustGiving sends your donation straight to Macmillan Cancer Support and automatically reclaims Gt Aidyou are a UK taxpayer, so your donation is worth even more.

Picture By: Arthur Allison Pacemaker Press.Centenary Poll age chartCentenary Poll age chartCentenary Poll: Male and female identitiesCentenary Poll chartCentenary Poll chart FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueOverall, the exclusive Belfast -Kantar poll shows a third of all people living in Northern Ireland now consider themselves Northern Irish. Picture By: Arthur Allison Pacemaker Press.Gareth CrossTwitterEmailMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailBritish identity is on the decline in Northern Ireland with more and more younger people identying as Northern Irish, a poll reveals today.While % of over-s here consider themselves British, just % of those aged - feel the same way.There is a less notable rise in those considering themselves Irish - % of those aged + identy as Irish, compared with % aged between  and .The - age group has the highest percentage of people identying as Irish and Northern Irish, with the lowest who identy as British.There is a huge drop off in those who consider themselves British between the - age groupand those aged - Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseCentenary Poll age chart FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCentenary Poll age chartOverall, the exclusive Belfast -Kantar poll shows a third of all people living in Northern Ireland now consider themselves Northern Irish.One-thirdalso consider themselves British, % are Irish, with the rest either not saying or unsure.Read MoreSarah Creighton:OpinionWe want to define ourselves outside orange and green boundaries that labelled our parents in pastAllison Morris:OpinionPracticalities will trump identity and ideology in any Irish Unity referendumJim Gracey:OpinionThose behind All Ireland football team don’t understand the psyche of fansAmong young people aged - the number of people who see themselves as Northern Irish hits a high of %. By contrast only % of those aged + declare as Northern Irish.The findings emerge on the day that Northern Ireland marks its centenary.They suggest the region has moved away from its traditional orange and green binary definitions and now has a distinct third group.Recent elections have also seen gains by the Alliance Party, which aims to attract support from across the two communities.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseCentenary Poll age chart FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCentenary Poll age chartIn a sign of the demographic shts, the number of people identying as Northern Irish is particularly high among younger age groups, with young people perhaps looking to shy away from the debates of the past.The all-island Kantar poll was commissioned in association with the Sunday Le, Irish Independent and Sunday Independent.It has also examined support for a border poll and a united Ireland, and concerns around the implications for health and wealthpartition was removed.The latest findings examine how respondents identied themselves.Under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement, people born in Northern Ireland are free to identy as British, Irish, both or neither. They are also entitled to hold British and Irish citizenship and passports.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseCentenary Poll: Male and female identities FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCentenary Poll: Male and female identitiesMencurrently identy considerably more as British than women , with womenmore likely to feel Northern Irish than their male counterparts .In terms of the Irish identity, % of women said it best describes them, and % of men.The majority of Protestants identy as Britishand Catholics as Irish . Of Protestants, % feel Northern Irish as opposed to % of Catholics.A tiny numberof Protestants identy as Irish, with % of Catholics saying they are British.People from other religious backgrounds are much more likely to feel Britishthan Irish , while mostconsider themselves Northern Irish.Predictably the majority of unionists loyalists consider themselves British , with % declaring as Northern Irish and % Irish.Among nationalists and republicans % report being Irish, % Northern Irish and % British. Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseCentenary Poll chart FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCentenary Poll chartThe majority of those belonging to neither community consider themselves Northern Irish , with % British and % Irish.In Belfast city, identities are split fairly evenly between Irish , Britishand Northern Irish , reflecting the political ision within the area.In Greater Belfast the majority of people feel either Britishor Northern Irish , with % identying as Irish.The Irish identity is the most popular in the rest of Northern Ireland , with Northern Irishbeing more popular than British .Other findings of the poll showed that % of people in Northern Ireland would consider their political affiliation to be unionist and loyalist as opposed to % for nationalists and republicans.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseCentenary Poll chart FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCentenary Poll chartWith % saying their politics are neither, it reflects the identication results in suggesting Northern Ireland is now split into three groups.Groups with the highest number of people who consider their politics to be neither unionist or nationalist include young people aged -, those with no religion and those who consider themselves Northern Irish.The poll also found that most people in Northern Irelandstill opt for a British passport over an Irish one .Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic title: closing dates for northern ireland debenhams stores revealed
story: Shutting down: Debenhams store in Belfast Photo:Stephen Hamilton FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueShutting down: Debenhams store in Belfast Photo:Stephen HamiltonChristopher LeebodyTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe remaining Debenhams stores in Northern Ireland are set to shut for the final time later in May, after the company confirmed the official dates of closure.Debenhams announced the remaining  stores will close on  May and  May, after previous closing dates were announced last week.The Debenhams store in Ballymena will close on  May, while Belfast’s Castecourt will close its Debenham store on  May.The stores in Newry’s Quays shopping centre and Rushmere shopping centre in Craigavon will also close on  May.The retail giant collapsed into administration last year and reopened its physical stores after lockdown only to sell off its remaining stock.Some , workers in total within the company are losing their jobs, after efforts rescue the ailing store chain failed at the end of last year.Debenhams# Northern Ireland stores had been in lockdown for the first four months  due to Covid restrictions, but they were allowed to reopen along with other non-essential shops on  April.In a statement announcing closure dates for its remaining UK stores, a company spokesperson said: Over the next  days, Debenhams will close its doors on the high street for the final time in its -year history.Our sincere thanks go out to all of our colleagues and customers who have joined us on this journey.We hope to see you all one last time in stores before we say a final goodbye to the UK high street.Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist outbursts and showing porn title: coronavirus northern ireland over 18s to be offeredjab within a
story: Northern Ireland#s vaccination programme is to be expanded to tover-sREUTERS FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNorthern Ireland#s vaccination programme is to be expanded to tover-sLisa SmythTwitterMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailCovid- vaccines will be offered to people aged  and over within a matter of weeks, with Northern Ireland on target to vaccinate % of the eligible population.Patricia Donnelly, who heads up the vaccination programme, revealed she hoped to be in a position to open up appointment slots to anyone aged over  “within a few weeks”.She also suggested requirements by airlines for proof of vaccination prior to travel may encourage more young people to come forward for their jab.Ms Donnelly made the comments as she appeared in front of the Stormont Health Committee on Thursday to update it on the progress of the vaccination programme.Asked by SDLP MLA Cara Hunter about vaccine hesitancy, particularly in younger people, Ms Donnelly said: “The message is harder as you get younger because, as we know, young people are less affected by Covid.They’re not unaffected — they do get ill, they do get long Covid, they do get into hospital — but it is much rarer than those who are older.“So, I think it’s quite clear that there has to be a dferent kind of message to them because, yes, it is for their own protection, but it is also for the protection of others that younger people would get vaccinated.“I’m not going to be too cynical at the moment and say that some of the requirements airlines have in providing evidence of being vaccinated may have an impact on younger people who may feel disadvantagedthey are not vaccinated.“But from our point of view, it is voluntary and it must always remain voluntary for younger people. Therefore, they need to understand both the risks to themselves and the benefits to themselves of being vaccinated.”Ms Donnelly also said revised guidance saying people under  years old should be offered an alternative vaccine to the AstraZeneca jab was likely to encourage younger people to come forward.However, she said the change in guidelines, which was introduced in response to safety concerns over the AstraZeneca vaccine, had pushed back the scheduled completion date for the programme to August.She said: “We are not giving up on any of the age groups. We are still trying to target % uptake and we have good reason to believe that will be achieved.“However, with the recent JCVIadvice, you will understand that the programme now has to really conserve its steady supply of Pfizer.“We have had supply that has been steady and predictable and we are able to plan on the basis of it, but that means because we are not using very much of the AstraZeneca for the younger age population, it is now going to take us several more weeks to complete the programme.”Ms Donnelly also ruled out the possibility that the programme would be redesigned to offer the vaccine to people according to occupation.“We will get to everyone eventually,” she said.Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist title: number on furlough drops below 100000 in
story: Figures peaked at , in mid-January before falling to , at the end of March  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFigures peaked at , in mid-January before falling to , at the end of March Christopher LeebodyTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThere are now , furloughed jobs in Northern Ireland - down from a recent high of ,.The latest figures from HMRC reflect the recent moves to reopen the economy, with people in industries including hospitality and close contact services being taken off furlough to prepare for reopening.Figures peaked at , in mid-January before falling to , at the end of March - the latest date for which stats are available.The Coronavirus Job Retention Schemeruns until September.The scheme pays up to % of an employee#s salary, up to a maximum of £, a month.Newry, Mourne and Down and Causeway Coast and Glens had the highest take-up rates of the scheme at %.In Northern Ireland and the West Midlands, the wholesale and retail sector had the highest number of employees on furlough at  February, followed by accommodation and food services.Responding to the latest figures, Richard Ramsay, chief economist at Ulster Bank sounded a note of caution.“Northern Ireland’s unemployment rate has been kept articially low due to the arrival of the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme last year,” he said.“The second quarter should see a rapid descent in the number of employments furloughed with a progressive easing of lockdown restrictions at the end of April and again in late May.“The reopening of non-essential retail and the hospitality sector is expected to lead to a similar fall in furloughed employment that occurred last August and September.“Perhaps of more concern is the scale of furloughed employment within the manufacturing sector. This is arguably one of the least affected sectors from the ious lockdown restrictions.“Only  manufacturing jobs came off furlough in March relative to the previous month. That means a sizeable , jobs within manufacturing, or  in  of all jobs, are currently out of action.“The concern is that a signicant number of these jobs may be lost when the furlough scheme expires. That worry is not just confined to manufacturing but to other sectors too.“The lting of lockdown restrictions removes just one barrier to ato employment. For many of these furloughed jobs.“However, the even bigger hurdle is will the businesses employing them still be viable ”Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Simpsonmark carruthersdeclan harveybarra bestmark simpsonjohn campbellemily maitliss FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDetails of external work by BBC staff has been published.Lauren HarteTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailBarra Best, Mark Simpson and Declan Harvey are some of the big-name BBC presenters paid the most for outside work, a new register has revealed.For the first time, news and current affairs presenters must declare their earnings outside of the BBC for engagements including speaking and corporate events.The public service broadcaster announced last October that it would be publishing a quarterly summary of the paid-for external events undertaken by on-air staff “in order to promote the highest standards of impartiality”.Of the seven BBC Northern Ireland staff paid for external events since the start of the year, reporter Mark Simpson topped the list with four appearances.The corporation’s former Ireland correspondent hosted and chaired an event for Newry Chamber of Trade on February , followed by three other events the following month — for Intertrade Ireland on March , the Northern Ireland Hotels Federation on March  and the Dundalk and Newry chambers of trade the following day.According to the declaration published by the BBC, for each of the four external events he received a fee of up to £,.Also in demand was BBC NI economics and business editor John Campbell. He was a  chair for the Northern Ireland Chamber of Commerce on February  and a list at an event at Queen’s University in Belfast on March .Both of these were in the earnings bracket of up to £,.Also listed is BBC NI weatherman and presenter Barra Best, who hosted an event for Charter NI and the Short Strand Community Forum on February . He received a fee under £,, as did his colleague and Radio Ulster presenter and producer Nicola Weir when she chaired a  for Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon City Council on February .Business correspondent Clodagh Rice was listed for chairing a  for Belfast’s politan Arts Centre on March , while political journalist and presenter Mark Carruthers hosted an event for the Northern Ireland Bureau in Washington on March .BBC Radio Ulster’s Evening Extra presenter Declan Harvey hosted an event for Bryson on March .All of the above were also in the less than £, category.Across the network, Radio  Today presenter Justin Webb, who earns more than £, at the BBC, appears most often in the “£, or above” tier for speaking or hosting events for the Chartered Institute for Securities  Investment, City Wealth Magazine, management consultancy Proxima and the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders.Newsnight presenter Emily Maitlis earned more than £, for hosting an event for commercial law firm Mason Hayes and Curran on top of her £, BBC salary, while fellow host Kirsty Wark is recorded in the category as a moderator for the WISH Foundation for Global Health.Veteran presenter Andrew Marr, who earns £,, also received over £, for hosting an event for investment management firm Brewin Dolphin.Today presenter Mishal Husain registered a £,-plus payment from World , while BBC Breakfast’s Naga Munchetty received less than £, to interview a guest for online events company Fane.The engagements registered are for Zoom and webinar appearances, with live conferences still not permitted under Covid- restrictions.The BBC said around % of all appearances, which include full-time and part-time staff, were for a fee below £,, with % of these under £,.Staff must seek written approval from a isional head of department before signing up to any external engagements.A BBC spokesman said: “The BBC’s robust and longstanding editorial guidelines permit staff to carry out additional engagements as long as they do not compromise the integrity or impartiality of the BBC.“The register was announced last October and launched in January as part of a series of measures to ensure the highest standards of impartiality across the organisation. New staff guidance on impartiality and social media use was published last year and new impartiality training was rolled out in January.”Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic title: seven confirmed cases of covid 19 indian variant detected in
story: Dr Michael McBride FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDr Michael McBrideChristopher LeebodyTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailSeven confirmed cases of the so-called Indian coronavirus iant have been detected in Northern Ireland, according to the Department of Health.The department said they had been notied by the Public Health Agency of what is known as the VUI B...iant.The Department of Health said they are working closely with the PHA and Regional Virology Laboratory to investigate the cases further.Describing it as “note entirely unexpected”, the chief medical officer Dr Michael McBride confirmed “plans are in place” to deal with the presence of the iant.The Department of Health has been notied by the Public Health Agency of seven confirmed cases of the VUI B...Coronavirus iant in Northern Ireland.â¡ï¸https:t.co UKlYHtTGI pic zwaeoiEBN— Department of HealthMay , “While preventative measures – including travel restrictions – are very important, the assessment is that these will delay rather than permanently prevent the spread of iants already detected where on these islands,” he said.“Confirmation of these cases does not mean this iant is going to become the most prevalent or the dominant strain in Northern Ireland.“It does, however, highlight why caution is still essential in relation to Covid-.“The most effective way to stop iants developing or spreading is to keep pushing down infection rates and transmission of the virus in our community.“All iants spread in the same way. We protect ourselves and others by following public health advice and getting vaccinated when our turn comes.“Social distancing and limiting the number of contacts we have are still vitally important. So too are wearing a face covering and washing hands well and often.“Also, please always remember the particular risks from indoor settings, especially those that are crowded and have poor ventilation.”The Indian iant of Covid- has been detected in other parts of the UK and the Republic of Ireland.Health officials in London suggest almost % of coronavirus cases there now relate to the Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoIn Focus:WeekendCoronavirusBelfast BeatNewsletter sign-upBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumCentenary poll: Health and wealth key issues in Irish unication debateSuzanne BreenExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseEconomic recovery of the UK and Republic is key to the unity debate FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEconomic recovery of the UK and Republic is key to the unity debateMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailDebate on a border poll has so far focused largely on flags and anthems, but our survey suggests that health and wealth are key issues on which a referendum on Irish unity will succeed or fail.The future health system and taxes matter at least as much to people as what happens the Tricolour and Amhrán na bhFiann.The DUP would do well to focus on these findings as it chooses its future leader. Read MoreCentenary poll: % in Northern Ireland want referendum but would not accept higher taxes to fund reunicationCentenary poll suggests only % of people in Northern Ireland consider Irish language to be importantEsmond Birnie:OpinionOur economy needs recuperation, not a constitutional shockThe Union would be better served by making strong economic arguments for its preservation, rather than politicians heading down the rabbit hole of poking their noses into people#s bedrooms and private lives.Our poll findings suggests that nationalists have a job of work to do to make a strong financial case for a united Ireland, although that is certainly not an impossible task.!fordocument.querySelectortThe Scottish Government produced a -page white paper laying out the case for independence in . There is no sign that a similarly comprehensive blueprint is on the horizon from nationalists here.Our poll indicates that the strongest argument unionists could employ is that Irish unity would hit people in their pockets on both sides of the border.More than half in Northern Ireland think they#d be worse off with just % believing they#d prosper. But % of people were unsure, meaning that the economic arguments on both sides really need to be formed and aired.!fordocument.querySelectortIn the Republic, four in  thought they#d be worse off in a united Ireland, one in five disagreed, and a staggering % didn#t know. If RTE hasn#t already planned it, another Claire Byrne Live to shed light on this part of the debate would be warmly welcomed.A majority on both sides of the border said they wouldn#t be prepared to pay more taxes to fund Irish unity.!fordocument.querySelectortNorthern Ireland currently receives a £bn annual subvention from Westminster. Almost half of people in the Republic said they#d match thator pay some of it . A third were totally opposed to doing so.But the £bn figure is disputed. It#s the UK statistical calculation that encompasses costs which nationalists believe wouldn#t transfer to a new united Ireland. Those costs include UK government debt interest, contributions to the UK armed forces and pension liabilities.!fordocument.querySelectortStill, Northern Ireland#s low cost of living and high number of public sector jobs will be extremely successful weaponsunionists are forced to do battle in a border poll.The jewel in the crown will of course be the NHS. Six in  voters here would be uncomfortable about transferring to the Republic#s health service.Changing it to a system similar to the NHS with free access and no prescription charges would surely be essential for nationalists in a future referendum. The British Treasury footing the bill during the pandemic for the furlough scheme also gives unionists strong ammunition.However, nationalists will be able to use Northern Ireland#s poor infrastructure, low wages, and very small private sector in their arguments. They will also suggest that considerable economic opportunities and potential investment could open up in the event of Irish unity.This poll gives Irish unity campaigners many reasons to pause for thought. Yet it also counters claims made by those who oppose constitutional change. The idea that the south doesn#t want the north is contradicted.More than two-thirds of people in the Republic support Irish unity with just % against.In Northern Ireland, there was a clear pro-Union lead - % to %, with % undecided.Some % of people here want a border poll compared to % opposed in the Republic two-thirds want one. Among referendum supporters, seven in  on both sides of the border want one now or within five years. Those figures suggest that the Taoiseach, who has dragged his feet on the issue and ruled out a border poll in coming years, is out of step with voters.The th anniversary of the Good Friday Agreement in  is the date many nationalists are now speaking of for a referendum.The economic recovery of both the UK and the Republic post-pandemic will be key to the unity debate. Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoIn Focus:WeekendCoronavirusBelfast BeatNewsletter sign-upBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumOur economy needs recuperation, not a constitutional shockEsmond BirnieExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseA week ago, the London-based Institute for Government confirmed that Northern Ireland receives a sizeable subsidy of more than £bn: we get more back than we pay into the UK tax and public spending systemPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA week ago, the London-based Institute for Government confirmed that Northern Ireland receives a sizeable subsidy of more than £bn: we get more back than we pay into the UK tax and public spending systemMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailUS President Harry Truman once said, How far would Moses have gonehe had taken a poll in Egypt  Usefully, the Kantar Belfastpoll includes some of the practicalities, such as cash and healthcare.A week ago, the London-based Institute for Government confirmed that Northern Ireland receives a sizeable subsidy of more than £bn: we get more back than we pay into the UK tax and public spending system.That fiscal deficit doesn#t necessarily equal the financial cost of a united Ireland, but it is signicant. Those who favour a united Ireland have responded in a number of ways to this situation:Deny the figures - yes, about £bn of the transfer is an attributing to NI of spending done by the UK central government . But, in a united Ireland surely some of such spending would continue Claim taxes could rise - they could, but, as this poll shows, there would be considerable opposition to that, especially in the Republic.Claim public spending in NI could be scaled back - it is one thing to argue our public sector is too large in relative terms, but any sudden adjustment would probably provoke a major recession. Claim a united Ireland could out-grow the problem - true, in recent years the Republic#s economic growth rate has surpassed that in NI, even discounting the tax-avoiding behaviour of multinationals, but can we really assume that unity per se would have a sudden transformative impact on NI#s economic performance Claim that the Dublin government could borrow to keep NI afloat - at the moment, interest rates are very low, but that won#t always be true.Argue that the UK Government would leave its cheque book behind - in the s, the London government wrote off the Irish Free State#s obligation for part of the UK#s public debt, but can we really imagine a UK government being so generous as to wipe out debt and continue to pay for some welfare benefitsand subsidise NI#s infrastructure To be fair, this existence of the big fiscal deficit is also problematic for unionists. They could claim other UK regions have deficits. They do, but none are so large. They could try to argue this is a form of UK solidarity payment, but will that really wash with taxpayers in south-east England The biggest danger is that a long-term dependency on subsidy from Great Britain has actually distorted economic behaviour. As RHI exemplied, free money trumps making necessary reforms.One particularly interesting area of Northern Ireland-Republic comparisons is healthcare: a major focus of the Kantar Belfastpoll.The south uses a mixture of state provision and private insurance. The polling response shows a very strong preferences in NI to continue with the NHS model. That said, the advantages of free at the point of use are blunted by our ening waiting lists.OECD data implies healthcare spending per person in the Republic now exceeds that in NI and the UK average.Of course, as indicated by US experience, very high spending does not necessarily bring better quality. We know the dference in Covid vaccination rates.To finish with a health analogy, for all its points of strength, the NI economy remains in need of intensive care - a period of recuperation, rather than a major constitutional shock is probably the priority.Dr Esmond Birnie is senior economist at Ulster UniversityBelfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist outbursts and showing porn to colleaguesBobby Sands burial wishes ignored in favour of ‘political beneficial’ Belfast funeralFormer Fermanagh businessman James Balmer  charged with historical sexual abuseRevealed: the BBC NI presenters paid the most for external work‘Tough loss’ for Belfast as Holohans at the Barge restaurant announces closureTop VideosPlayWatch: Suzanne Breen gives her take on the DUP leadership racePlayPro-united Ireland poster removed from Divis Tower in Belfast PlayTrial of two veterans accused of IRA leader murder collapsesLatest The CentenaryThree young voices... why I feel Northern Irish, why I feel British and why I feel IrishCentenary poll: Public ided on terror amnesties as pardons for terrorists and troops leave people tornSuzanne BreenOpinionNorthern Ireland#s a powderkeg... but will of people must always prevailCentenary poll: #Irish unity would jeopardise peace in Northern Ireland# - Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownPoliticsGeneral Election RHI ScandalBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumEdwin Poots pledges to restore DUP’s fortunes as he publishes manesto Minister publishes manesto and says he will reform internal structures of DUPhe wins Suzanne BreenTwitterEmailMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailEdwin Poots says he will reform the DUP’s internal structures “from top to bottom” and attempt to win back voters’ trusthe becomes the party’s next leader.In a four-page glossy manesto for MLAs and MPs, he said the work ahead is “considerable” but he vowed to restore DUP fortunes. “Only by maximising unionism will we silence and repel our opponents and give a resounding response to persistent calls for a isive and unwanted border poll,” he added.Mr Poots pledged to replace his party’s current ministerial line-up at Stormont and also to reshuffle its Assembly committees team. He outlined plans for a unionist convention ahead of next year#s election to maximise unionist representation.Read MorePoots vs Donaldson: Tale of the tape as DUP heavyweights square off for party leadership Read MoreNelson McCausland:OpinionDUP must recover its passion... and new leader has to deliverThe Agriculture Minister promised an extensive outreach programme across unionism and loyalism to address issues of marginalisation, disadvantage and to rebuild communities. He said that he would set up a pro-Union think-tank including civic and political figures to broaden support for the Union to avoid a border poll.He would engage in international outreach to better explain the unionist cause in Brussels, London and North America. Mr Poots confirmed that he would split the positions of DUP leader and First Minister as one person simply cannot do justice to both demanding jobs. Instead of acting as First Minister, he would oversee the work of a new ministerial team and the day-to-day running of the party. Vowing to transform it totally, he said he would put democracy back into the Democratic Unionist Party.He pledged to order an independent review of the DUP with a view to creating a new, fit-for-purpose modern political party. He also announced plans to reach out to the grassroots of the party and to attract new members.The Agriculture Minister, who is expected to remain in that posthe becomes leader, said he wanted to ensure the effective running of the Executive through constructive engagement, but he would challenge republican propaganda and shameless populism”.He said he would lead a campaign against the “undemocratic protocol”. He also pledged to bridge the gap, and ensure “effective collaboration”, between DUP representatives in the Assembly and at Westminster in all policy areas.Meanwhile, Deputy First Minister Michelle O’Neill has said she felt sorry for Arlene Foster over the way she was treated by her party colleagues. She repeated her view that misogyny played a part in the internal DUP revolt that forced Mrs Foster to resign as DUP leader. Ms O#Neill would not be drawn on who she would prefer to win the leadership contest between Edwin Poots and Sir Jeffrey Donaldson.However, she said her relationship with whoever emerged victorious had to be one that was based on mutual respect and delivering outstanding political commitments from the New Decade, New Approach deal to restore powersharing at Stormont, including Irish language legislation.She said: I am joint head of government, I want to work with the leader of unionism but that needs to be on the basis of mutual respect, it needs to be on the basis of delivering political commitments that have been made.We had three years of hiatus, we had a political agreement in New Decade, New Approach. There are many outstanding commitments that haven#t been delivered, some because of Covid, some because there hasn#t been a full agreement to deliver in terms timeframe. I look forward to delivering on all the commitments of NDNA, including an Irish Language Act, women#s reproductive rights, rights right across the board.”Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownPoliticsGeneral Election RHI ScandalBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremiumFormer Presbyterian moderator joins ex-IRA man on SDLP’s Irish unity groupExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseSigning up: Richard O’Rawe will be on the new commission FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSigning up: Richard O’Rawe will be on the new commissionSuzanne BreenTwitterEmailMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA former Presbyterian moderator and an ex-IRA prisoner are among a wide range of members in the SDLP’s New Ireland Commission launched today, which will contribute to the conversation about Irish unity.Richard O#Rawe, who was the IRA prisoners# public relations officer and drafted the statement announcing the start of their  hunger-strike, will sit with former Presbyterian moderator, Dr Norman Hamilton, on the commission.Mr O’Rawe said: “I’m looking forward to sitting down with people from very dferent backgrounds than my own to discuss the shape of a future Ireland. The commission is a very progressive body and hearing a range of perspectives will be invaluable.There is so much work to do. If there’s a future referendum, people need to know what sort of Ireland they’re voting for.”Dr Hamilton said: “I am delighted that the SDLP have reached out beyond the usual political activists to people of faith like me. I didn’t hesitate for a second in agreeing to come on board.I will be sitting on the commission as a Christian minister, and not as an armchair politician.”Dr Hamilton said he would “be surprised”he didn’t face criticism for joining the commission. “Some people will struggle to understand why a former Presbyterian moderator would want to be part of a discussion on Irish unity,” he said.“It’s important to remember that Presbyterians weren’t always unionists. It may seem strange, and a bit unpalatable now, but historically Presbyterians have been on both sides of the constitutional question here. The United Irishmen were radical Presbyterians.”Askedhe was a unionist or a nationalist, the former moderator said: “The unionism I come from is being changed by what is happening in London and Edinburgh. The underpinnings of the Union are being challenged by a rising English nationalism. It’s no longer clear to me what a unionist is.Dr Hamilton may head a policy think-tank on the role of faith communities in a new Ireland. “The Catholic Church’s relationship with the Irish state has a dficulty history so this would be important  work,” he said.Other  members included ex-NIO political director Chris McCabe former joint leader of the Green Party NI, Professor John Barry Lilian Seenoi Barr of the North West Migrants Forum victims’ campaigner Jude Whyte and disabled rights’ activist Michaela Holywood.Former Policing Board vice-chair Denis Bradley civic activist Conor Houston Dublin barrister Brian Barrington and Northern Ireland’s former chief probation officer Breidge Gadd are also members.SDLP leader Colum Eastwood said: “This is the beginning of the real conversation about what type of society we want to be. Instead of platitudes and demands, the SDLP is rolling up our sleeves to work with people across our communities, to have the dficult conversations and to bring forward the practical detail that has been lacking from the constitutional debate.”Belfast Most ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist outbursts and showing porn to colleaguesBobby title: varadkar outright ban on investment funds purchasing homes would be a mistake
story: Tanaiste Leo Varadkar  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueTanaiste Leo Varadkar By Michelle Devane, PAMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailAn outright ban on investment funds buying complete housing estates would be “wrong” and a “mistake”, the Dail has heard.Tanaiste Leo Varadkar said it would be “ideologically extreme” to ban investment on certain types of housing in the country.He added that investment funds have a “role to play” in the property market.His comments come following controversy earlier this week over a housing development in Maynooth, Co Kildare, where  of  houses at the Mullen Park estate were purchased by two investment funds, to be put up for rent.Opposition parties have warned first-time buyers are being priced out of the market, because they cannot compete financially with such funds.Taoiseach Micheal Martin on Wednesday described the practice as “unacceptable”.It needs to be a solution that resolves this problem, but also needs to be a solution that doesn#t have unintended consequencesTanaiste Leo VaradkarOn Thursday, Mr Varadkar was pressed on the matter in the Dail by Sinn Fein’s Pearse Doherty who said the Government had not only “facilitated” but “incentivised” and “rolled out the red carpet” for investment funds.Mr Doherty said: “You’ve created this situation where these international investment funds are snapping up family homes and locking first-time buyers out of the market.“That is the reality. You’ve frustrated the hopes and dreams and aspirations of many workers and families who aspire to own their own homes.”Fine Gael and Fianna FÃ¡il are both to blame for the housing crisis. They rolled out the red carpet for these funds to swoop in to buy up family homes. They created the system  turbo-charged it for years, while opposing our plans to stop it. #homesnotinvestments @PearseDoherty pic sykxOdGK— Sinn FÃ©inMay , In response, Mr Varadkar said the Government believes in home ownership and is in the process of developing proposals for a “workable solution”.“It needs to be a solution that resolves this problem, but also needs to be a solution that doesn’t have unintended consequences,” he told the Dail.The Tanaiste added that investment funds “have a role to play” in the property market.“There are housing developments in this city, mainly apartment blocks, mainly high-density developments that would not have been builtthey haven’t got finance from investment funds,” he said.“They weren’t able to get funds from the banks, andthey had not been built, we’d have fewer apartments, higher rents, higher prices, and perhaps even more people at homelessness.”Mr Varadkar said that at present about % of the housing stock in Ireland is owned by investment funds, which is “much lower” than in other developed countries.“Their correct role is to finance the construction of developments, not to swoop in and buy housing estates or developments that are already substantially complete,” he said.“That’s what we need to change and that’s what the Government intends to change with the actions it’s going to take in the coming weeks.”He added that it would be “wrong to ban them outright”.The Tanaiste was also pressed on the matter by Social Democrats co-leader Roisin Shortall and People Before Profit’s Richard Boyd Barrett.Ms Shortall said Fine Gael and Fianna Fail were arguing over who was to blame for the country’s housing issues when both were to blame.“Fianna Fail crashed the housing market the first time round, and Fine Gael then let vulture funds loose on the carcass for a decade, with tax incentives and fast-track planning and now both parties have joined forces and have been destroying the housing market,” she said.She questioned whether anyone in Government had noticed that since  funds have spent four billion euro on residential property in this country.Fianna FÃ¡il crashed the housing market and Fine Gael let vulture funds loose on its carcass for a decade.Time for action, not lip service.The @SocDems are bringing forward a Bill today to end the practice of the State entering long-term leases with developers  investors. pic hSUINvLh— RÃ³isÃ­n ShortallMay , Responding, Mr Varadkar said: “What I think is ideologically extreme is the view from some, including as I understand the Social Democrats, that we should have outright bans on some forms of housing and outright bans on some forms of housing investment, I think that would be a mistake.”He added that he believed any such ban would result in less housing.PAMost ReadAstonishing antics of NI hospital medic revealed: Doctor Tsakov admits to lewd and racist outbursts and showing porn to colleaguesBobby Sands burial wishes ignored in favour The owner of a Derry cafe will be delivering free turkey dinners with all the trimmings to the needy on Christmas Day.Paula Monk has been running Peggy’s Kitchenin The Old Library Trustin Creggans Central Drive for over a year.Last Christmas she and her business partner Adam Nabaz delivered over  free Christmas dinners and this year they will be doing it all over again.The need in the community this year is greater than ever because of the coronavirus, said Ms Monk. So Ill be in the kitchen prepping on Christmas Eve and then the dinner will be cooked and delivered on Christmas Day for anyone who’s alone or in need of one.Last year we actually had some spare meals left over so I went and delivered them up to the Fire Station, which was the highlight of my Christmas, she said.Paula has been provided with the names of people in the local community who would benefit from the scheme by the Operation Snowball at the OLT and staff at the Long Tower Youth Club.This service is free of charge of course, soyou or someone you know needs help this Christmas please send me a message to the Peggys Kitchen Facebook page,continued Ms Monk. googletag.cmd.push Last year we covered the cost of it ourselves, apart from the desserts, but this year Foyle Fruit have kindly offered to donate the potatoes and vegetables and we have also had donations of containers and cups. All donations are welcome andanyone wishes to help our efforts that help would be much appreciated.Ms Monk has enlisted the help of two delivery drivers to take the food to the Bogside, Brandywell and Creggan areas of the city.Like all cafes, Peggys Kitchen is closed at the moment due to current restrictions.Its sad that we cant open because we really miss our customers like the Over s Club that used to meet here every Wednesday and for a lot of them it was their only source of interaction but the safety of everyone needs to come first, said Ms Monk. googletag.cmd.push We cant wait to reopen again but until then please keep safe.      --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories.
