title: things south wales may bank holiday weekend
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityHere are some ideas of what you can do in South Wales this bank holiday weekendhellipGo to a funfairMissing the dizzying excitement of the funfair or would you rather dodgem Thrill seekers looking for a ride have a few options in South Wales - here are a few:James Danter  Sons Fun Fair will be in Caldicot RFC, on Longfellow Road in Caldicot, from Friday to Monday, and will help raise funds for the venue. The fair will be open from pm to pm on Saturday , Sundayand Monday . Tokens are used for entry and rides. For more information visit www.facebook Danters.funfairAlternatively, Barry Islands Pleasure Park has also re-opened its funfair. Entry to the park is free, with tokens for the rides and ample parking. For more information visit www.barryislandpleasurepark.wales Coney Beach Pleasure Park, in Porthcawl, will be open over the Bank Holiday weekend with a new ride for this season: Top Scan. Tokens will be required for rides. Wristbands can be bought on the gate, but there is a  per cent discount when you book online at least  hours in advance with the funfair offering daytime sessionsor evening sessions . For more information visit www.coneybeach Go somewhere beautulTheres an abundance of beautul places in South Wales - too numerous to list them all - including National Trust sites.Although their houses are currently closed, people are welcome to visit their gardens, parks and countryside locations. Booking in advance is recommended to avoid disappointment with visitors asked to check the website before visiting and follow government guidelines.Here are the National Trust sites currently open, to some extent, in South Wales:Tredegar House in NewportLanlay [meadows] in Vale of GlamorganDyffryn Gardens in Vale of Glamorgan     The Kymin [grounds] in MonmouthSugar Loaf [mountain] and Usk Valley in AbergavennySkenfrith Castle in AbergavennyLearn about Welsh historyAlthough many museums in Wales are currently closed due to coronavirus restrictions, the open-air St Fagans National Museum of History in Cardf is open to the public, with safety measures in place.Entry is free, but - due to restricted numbers - people are asked to book tickets in advance. Only the main entrance is open so those arriving by car will need to book and pay for a parking space in advance - its pound a day or free for disabled badge holders and motorbikes. Children under  must be accompanied by an adult at all timesSt Fagans will be open throughout the Bank Holiday weekend, including Bank Holiday Monday. Although buildings and galleries are closed the public can explore the grounds and the history and origins of the buildings. Plus visitors can experience nature and see farm animals in the -acre parkland.Toilets swill be open, with an improved hygiene schedule, and visitors must wear face coverings in indoor spaces.You can find out more of book tickets here.Explore castle groundsAs previously mentioned National Trusts Skenfrith Castle, in Abergavenny, is open to the public.Cadw also has a number of South Wales sites - including castles - which are open, including:Caerphilly CastleChepstow CastleTretower Court and CastleBlaenavon IronworksRaglan CastleTintern Abbey Although its not a Cadw site, Fonmon Castles Grounds in Barry are open - with people required to book in advance. For more information or to book a space visit www.fonmoncastle Go to the beachSome may want to keep it simple and enjoy some fresh air and sand between their toes.Rest Bay in Porthcawl is a Blue Flag beach with golden sands and great views - no dogs are allowed between May  and September .Dunraven Bay, a.k.a Southerndown Beach, has great rock pools and scenic views - no dogs are allowed between May  and September .Ogmore-by-Sea is another golden sand beach, with dogs welcome all year round.Aberthaw Beach, a.k.a Limpert Bay, is a wide shingled beach which is good for fishing, with dogs welcome all year round.Penarth Beach is lovely for a stroll, but not suitable for those looking to swim due to strong currents - no dogs are allowed between May  and September .Whitmore Bay on Barry Island is open to the public - no dogs are allowed between May  and September .Jackson Bay on Barry Island is also open with dogs welcome all year round.Cold Knap Bay in Barry is a pebble beach and rock pools revealed at low tide - no dogs are allowed between May  and September . article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: poundland trial new service part biggest transformation history
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe service is not yet available to the general public, with the option to order items onlineonly available to the firmrsquos , workers and ldquoselected guests in its trial period.The scheme was launched without fanfare in February, and is currently thought to offer over , products, with a former Poundland store in Cannock, Staffordshire serving as the central hub from which orders are fulfilled.When can I take part in the trial The store chain has said the pilot will be opened up to the public ldquoin due course, reports the MirrorThe retailer has also announced it will trial click and collect services at some point. This may have already rolled out to workers in a similar trial format, but this has not been confirmed.A Poundland spokesperson said: "The launch of a pilot online service is just one part of our exciting transformation plans, offering customers new ranges and new services."David Jinks MILT, head of consumer research at Parcel Hero, told the Mirror: ldquoThe pandemic has taken its toll on our town centres and therersquos no going backhellip Poundland has belatedly woken up and smelled its discounted coffee. Although the initial trial is low-key, it is taking e-commerce seriously.lsquoThe biggest transformation in our historyrsquoNews of a Poundland delivery service first came in July , when the chain said it would trial such a service and refurbish a raft of high street stores as part of the ldquobiggest transformation in its history.It said it will also split its store estate into ldquoconvenience stores for customers to quickly purchase products and ldquocore stores which will offer a wider iety of products on high streets.The transformation plan, dubbed Project Diamond, will also see it open new stores in the UK and Ireland.     Unlike many other retailers, Poundland had a relatively steady  in the face of coronavirus restrictions, thanks in part toits status as an essential retailer and strong demand for expanded clothing and homewares ranges.It opted to temporarily close certain sites despite being allowed to remain open, and said sales among stores that traded throughoutthe year rose.In October, it bought frozen food retailer Fultons Foods as it looks to ramp up its food offering, and hasaccelerated the roll-out of chilled and frozen food to  stores.Barry Williams, Poundland managing director, said: ldquoThis is the biggest transformation in our history as we look to secure our future for another  years.Earlier this month, the owner of Poundland announced plans to list its shares in Warsaw instead of London, in its multibillion-pound stock market float.Pepco, which also runs the PepCo and Dealz brands, had previously said that it was considering stock exchanges in the UK and Poland.The listing price and total valuation has not yet been disclosed, although it is reported by Sky to be worth about pound billion.Pepco trades from , stores across  European countries, including more than , stores in Poland.A version of this article originally appeared on our sister title, NationalWorldGet involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: line dutys kelly macdonald says top cast know identity h
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMacdonald, who plays the guest lead in the latest seriesJoanne Davidson, also said she did not know about a pivotal twist about her characterrsquos parentage until halfway through filming.Series six of the BBC One crime drama comes to an end on Sunday, but a number of characters remain under suspicious in the hunt for the ldquothe fourth man ndash an inidual commanding a network of corrupt officers behind the murder of journalist Gail Vella.The penultimate episode of the police procedural, created by Jed Mercurio, earned an average of  million viewers and .% of the audience share, according to the broadcaster.The sixth series of the BBC One show, starring Compston as DI Steve Arnott alongside Vicky McClure, Adrian Dunbar and Kelly Macdonald, will come to an end this weekend .A seventh series has not yet been announced.The showrsquos creator, Jed Mercurio, whose credits also include Bodyguard and Bodies, said: ldquoThanks so much to everyone watching #LineofDuty. The whole production team is thrilled and flattered by the amazing response.Macdonald, , described Mercurio as ldquotroublesome when speaking to the PA news agency.She said: ldquoJed Mercurio, man, he is troublesome. He keeps a lot to himself. I feel like Martinalways heard about things first. I felt like he would get the lay of the land.ldquoI donrsquot knowthat was just because he is so on top of everything and understands everything acutely and what the connotations are.ldquoI didnrsquot have the full story on Jo. I just knew that things hadnrsquot been great for her. Jed kept saying, lsquoShe is this enigmatic figurersquo and he was being enigmatic himself.ldquoBy the time we came back after the first lockdown I knew what was up.Speaking about which stars know the identity of H, she added: ldquoThe main cast know. I donrsquot know about everybody. H knows who H ishellip Like I said, I donrsquot know the whole cast, but I know the top cast.     The Trainspotting star admits she has become more ldquoreclusive since the start of series six.ldquoIt has just been odd. I canrsquot tell you how odd it has all been. I just got told the numbers fromand it is a lot, she said.Itrsquos just a lot of people watching it and I am still in the living room, not going online and not watching. It feels like a slightly dferent dimension.The Line of Duty series final airs on BBC One and iPlayer on Sunday at pm. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"Comments are closed on this article. -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: aberthaw nuclear fusion power plant near barry must debated
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityVale of Glamorgan council put forward Aberthaw, a recently closed coal-fired power plant, as a potential site for a fusion prototype.The UK government last year called for suggestions for possible sites to pioneer the technology which could generate electricity with low carbon emissions.But opposition councillors on the Vale council have claimed the cabinet has ldquorushed through its decision to suggest Aberthaw as a site.More NewsCardf Tomasz Waga murder investigation sees two more arrestedFour coffee shops in Penarth for meeting a friend outdoorsThings to do in South Wales on May Bank Holiday weekend Plaid Councillor Ian Johnson said: ldquoIt was strange that the council leadership did not consult with other parties or ask a cross-party scrutiny committee to consider issues before making the expression of interest about a possible future use of the Aberthaw plant.ldquoEven though it is an early point, many people will have questions about the technology, the impact of the development and the process, and discussing this in scrutiny would open up the debate and ensure transparency.Fusion technology is still in its infancy and no fusion reactor has ever created more power than it consumes. But scientists say it could be cleaner and safer than fission, the nuclear technology currently used to generate electricity.If Aberthaw is chosen, the council is hoping the power plant could bring lots of high-tech high-paid jobs to the region. Westminster should decide on a site by the end of next year, and the power plant would be built by , costing about pound billion.But the Valersquos cabinet used controversial emergency powers last month to put forward Aberthaw as a site, without consulting the full council or any scrutiny committees. Council leader Neil Moore said this was due to the deadline for suggestions at the end of last month.     However, Westminster made the initial call for suggestions in December last year, meaning the council had four months in total to debate and scrutinise the decision to put forward Aberthaw. The council debated the issue in a meeting this week, after the deadline passed.Conservative Cllr Gordon Kemp said: ldquoThis is being dealt effectively without allowing any proper consideration or scrutiny. Itrsquos an extremely signicant matter, evenwe ignore the issue of public concern over such a proposal.ldquoWersquore looking at potentially a colossal, massive investment in the Vale. It could create many jobs, so I think itrsquos something that should have been discussed.ldquoI appreciate there are always deadlines on this. But Irsquom very concerned and surprised this wasnrsquot put before cabinet and scrutiny committees [earlier].Cllr Moore said the issue was ldquonot a debate, but promised to meet with the leaders of the opposition parties on the council, and to give a cross-party scrutiny committee a chance to consider the plans.He said: ldquoThis is just for noting. We used the emergency procedure because it had to be in by a deadline. This is not a debate about what we can do.ldquoBut Irsquom more than happy to have a meeting with the group leaders, and Irsquom more than happy to ask for an information report to go to the environment and regeneration scrutiny committee. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new nextbike station opened cosmeston country park
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityA fleet of  e-bikes first came to the town in November last yearand five stations were launched, by global bike share operator nextbike, with funding from the Vale of Glamorgan Council.This was based on the success of the nextbike cycle hire scheme in Cardf in just two years the Cardf bike scheme has clocked up more than , rentals.E-bikes are similar to normal bikes, but with a motor - meaning less dficulty peddling and cyclists reaching top speeds of km per hour, ideal for longer distance journeys.The stations are located at the Esplanade, Llandough Hospital, Rindsor Road, Penarth Train Station and the Barrage and now Cosmeston Country Parks.The council ask that people use them responsibly andthe bike to another e-bike docking station in the Vale.If youre cycling around the park, please use the appropriate paths. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: penarth pier patrons association fate pavilion
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe meeting was called to hear about progress on reopening the Pavilion and community involvement in running events there.Spokesperson for the Pavilion community group, Phil Rapier told the Penarth Times: "We are most anxious to get a programme of events for the summer and develop a structure for active democratic participation from our Community to secure the Pavilions future."The Vale MD, Rob Thomas reported they had acquired the equipment and carried out maintenance and renovation. Theyd opened the Big Fresh cafe, which is a trading arm of the VOG council profitgoes back into the school meals service.They see the Pavilion restorationaspart of apackage of upgrading the Piers Kiosks and the Esplanade.With the cafe-baropen into thesummer evenings, the Pavilion would be open for evening events.The community group assured Mr Thomas that they are fully supportive of the renovation work and reopening the cafe but theres little time until May , when indoor activities will be permitted.Mr Thomas said the more volunteers the better, to get community buy-in.They are about to appoint a duty manager, who will deal with offers to run events and involving volunteers.Hes still thinking how to reach the wider community and be as inclusiveas possible.The community group believe the lack of public engagement and public accountability by PACLcaused the charityrsquos long period in limbo and eventual failureThe Pavilion has limitations with one large hall and the cinema hardly usable at present.The group conceive its operations being integrated with the Kymin, in providing rehearsal space, meeting rooms and a possible local base for the Valersquos Radio Stations, Penarth Sounds and Bro Radio.     MORE NEWS:Tom Bowring, VoGHead of Policy  Businesspresented preliminary results from the on-line consultation  out of  responses were from Penarth residents.Favourite suggestions were for a coffee shop bar, produce markets, lightmusic and theatre.Young peoples activities had support, but exercise classes like yoga and Tai-chi got fewer mentions.People who are ready to re-start events such as the popular open mic sessions are invited to noty the duty Manager viaPavilion@valeofglamorgan.gov.uk.A report will go to next weeks Cabinet meeting , which should give a green light to re-opening the Pavilion.They hadnt yet thought about a publicised reopening event.The community group emphasises the importance of a democratically structured volunteer scheme.There are many successful community enterprises managed in this way, says their spokesperson Mr Thomas."The Blaenavon Hall is owned by their Town Council but has the distinct advantage of day-to-day running being chiefly in the hands of the Patrons," he added."Their scheme is regarded as a benchmark community resource that qualies for both Welsh Arts Council and Sporting Grant Funding in its own right."The Hall includes a Cinema exactly the same size as that at the Pier Pavilion."The Blaenavon Cinema regularly screens recent releases to packed audiences." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url title: look refurbished barry leisure centre gyms open
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityGyms, fitness facilities, leisure centres, spas and swimming pools reopened on Monday, after the Welsh Government brought forward the opening date from May .Leisure centres across the Vale have been welcoming members back since day one.However, Holm View Leisure Centre in Barry has not reopened as it is being used as a mass vaccination site.Barry Leisure CentreWe spoke with Council Cabinet Member for Leisure, Arts and Culture, Cllr Kathryn McCaffer about the reopening at Barry Leisure Centre andsaid that she had popped to the gym yesterday."It was amazing to go in there and see all the happy faces that are in there," she added.Cllr Kathryn McCaffer "People are so relieved to be back."As I was looking I could see all the sessions were being booked up. People were straight in there."Safety measures at the leisure centres in Barry, Penarth, Colcot, Cowbridge and Llantwit Major include:Additional cleaning - the facility is cleaned every two hoursOne-way systemsMasks in certain public areasEquipment has been distanced, with overflow being put into the dance rooms. When Wales went into lockdown again on December , the opportunity was taken by Legacy Leisureto finish off the sports hall in the leisure centre which now has brand new flooring and equipment.The refurbishment is nearly complete, with just the dry side changing rooms to go.The female changing rooms Drinking fountains are not currently available so it is advised to bring a full drinks bottle.Bookings can be made by visiting leisurecentre and selecting your local facility. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: senedd election  candidates cardiff south penarth
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityNasir Adam - Plaid CymruRaised in Butetown, the son and grandson of merchant navy, Irsquove lived in Cardf South my whole le and itrsquos where I still work and live and itrsquos here Irsquom raising my family. During my  years as a community campaigner I have passionately campaigned for education, creating more opportunities for young people, tackling the housing crisis and the climate crisis. I was the regeneration officer for the Loudoun Square and Trowbridge redevelopment, and was selected as the Wales delegate for the International Association for Community Development and Commonwealth Games in Glasgow . Over the last  years Irsquove supported young people in Cardf South and Penarth to develop their skills in the arts and creative industries and to participate in a wide range of opportunities. I successfully gained the London  Olympic Cultural Inspire Mark for Butetown Community. I entered politics because of the increasing injustice around me - increasing food banks, homelessness, education, climate crisis, lack of opportunity for our youth, lack of affordable housing I was sick and tired of our communities being treated like second class citizens by the London elite. I want a fair deal for our communities for Cardf South and Penarth and for Wales.Alan Golding - Freedom Alliance. No Lockdown. No CurfewsRaised in Tonyrefail, Rhondda Cynon Taff, I have since lived in Brighton and Glasgow, moving to Cardf in . Since my early twenties Irsquove been interested in the workings of society and how we treat each other, animals and our planethellip and in the process Irsquove come to completely mistrust virtually all career politicians. I believe a new way of doing politics is needed in Wales with a new set of values across the whole system. I donrsquot believe the current political structure and its controllers have the interest of the people at its heart with regard to their mental and physical health, their quality of le and spiritual and economic well-being.     Paul Campbell - UKIPHello Im Paul Campbell and Im standing in the Cardf South and South Wales Central area for UKIP in the Senedd elections on MAY TH.Being. Born in Cardf and lived most of my le there I appreciate the Greatv Potential the pride and the Welsh Identity in Cardf and the Valleys towns. and I have seen how things have changed over the years with parts of the area unrecognizable from the place I remember.Areas of Cardf have become run down and standards have fallen with a loss of community spirit The surrounding Towns have been neglected with. A lack of investment and job creation initiatives.Mass immigration in the UK has put tremendous strains on cities like Cardf Newport and Swansea with wage depression and overstretched public services.. The Conservatives claim to be in control of immigration but they will only ever talk about it and under there watch in the in the last  years  million more people have come to our shires thats  cities the sthe size of Cardf . Increasingly they are choosing to come to Wales as Labour has encouraged them by a making Wales a Nation Of sanctuary.Helen Westhead - Green PartyOur current administration has ignored the climate emergency and has left so many people vulnerable and excluded. As we recover from the pandemic we have unique opportunity to create better ways of working - the influence of an elected Green in the room will be transformative.We see from across the UK, Europe, and beyond the incredible dference Greens make, holding government to account, speaking out against inequality, and representing real people and their communities, not political or corporate interest. Wales is long overdue that representation in the Senedd.We know that the way we recover from this pandemic and build back stronger is through investing in communities and public services, ensuring everyone has access to local facilities, and supporting small business. If elected, one of my main priorities would be better walking and cycling routes, connected to affordable public transport and green outdoor spaces that communities can enjoy. Advocating for a Universal Basic Income would ensure no one is left behind in our bold plan to transform Wales.With the more proportional voting system on the regional ballot in Wales, Labour cannot win regional seats. A Green vote on your second ballot is the only progressive option.Matt Friend - PropelPropel has led the campaigns on two of the most important issues affecting Barry, Penarth and Cardf.Wersquore the only party that has committed not to allow any nuclear mud to be dumped in our waters, including the mud dredged from outside Hinkley nuclear reactor in Somerset.And wersquore the only party that even mentions the scandal of dangerous fire risk cladding on so many of our flats and buildings. Through our Contract with Wales we have committed not to issue new building contracts to any housing developer involved in the scandal, until they have paid to fix the problem they created.Wersquoll also end the way leaseholders are getting rinsed by introducing a service charge cap, linked to the Retail Price Index. That will stop the double digit increases in service charges that leaseholders have had to put up with.Most importantly, wersquoll introduce a Coronavirus Recovery Act to end Welsh lockdowns, save lives and restore freedoms. We canrsquot just hope wersquoll get our freedoms back, we have to vote for them.The ten laws in our Contract with Wales will transform our nation. Wales needs champions. Vote Propel.Alex Wilson, Liberal DemocratsI live with my family in Penarth and I became involved in politics because of the widening isions that seemed to occurring our community. I feel that with the Liberal Democrat core values of tolerance and understanding we can bring people back together. We can cut through the shouting of partisan politics and once again listen to what people want in their community.The next five years is going to be critical and I feel the Senedd must put recovery first. That means recovering from the Covid pandemic, the recovery of our economy, better healthcare services and a happier community which can be achieved by better transport links, saving our environment and ato community values.Irsquove been around long enough to know a political status-quo without a strong opposition can breed complacency. Wersquove seen this in national and local government. If I am elected I will ensure that the voice of the people is heard. If yoursquove ever wondered how we almost lost the Kymin or how they plan to build over  homes on contaminated land at Cosmeston Farm in Sully, well itrsquos because our current political leaders often lack empathy with local communities.Other candidates standing are:Vaughan Gething - LabourAngus Hawkins - Gwlad The Welsh Independence PartyLisa Peregrine ndash Abolish the Welsh Assembly Party Alan Pick ndash Reform UKDavid Rolfe ndash IndependentLeighton Rowlands ndash Conservative article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: penarth woman raises   memory childhood friend
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityVerity Louise Tucker, , completed the run on Saturday, May  after giving herself a month to prepare while currently undertaking a PGCSE to become a secondary school maths teacher.The run started in Talbot reen and ended in Cardf Bay by the Millennium Centre.Miss Tucker was joined by her two friends Zoe Fullbrook and Sian Smith, who agreed to join her in raising money for her friend Mason Ah-Mun who died on March ,  at the age of  to sudden arrythmia death syndrome . was joined by her two friends Zoe Fullbrook and Sian Smith" alt"Penarth Times: Miss Tuckerwas joined by her two friends Zoe Fullbrook and Sian Smith" class"editor-image"Miss Tuckerwas joined by her two friends Zoe Fullbrook and Sian SmithBoth were former pupils of Farfield Primary and in the same class.ldquoHe will always be in my heart and will be beside me each and every day - I hope I have and continue to make him proud. We love him and miss him so much, she said.ldquoI think his family are absolutely incredible, their strength and love is immense. You can totally see where Mason got his beautul personality from.Mason Ah-Mun died at the age of  ldquoI am so honoured to have been able to do this for them all. They will always have my heart.Masonrsquos family decided to set up a free phone app called MASwhich allows people to locate their closest defibrillator and can be used across the UK.Setting up an app costs money, so Maxine Ah-Mun, Masonrsquos mum, set up a small business selling soups.MORE NEWS:ldquoOne day I saw Maxine was selling soups during the week called @Soup_a_soup on Instagram, added Miss Tucker.ldquoShe sells them in Penarth and can be pre ordered by messaging her on Instagram or Facebook.ldquoI contacted Maxine, checking in on her, and asked about the app and how the money raising was going and askedI could help at all.      with his mum Maxine Ahmun and brother Benjamin Ahmun" alt"Penarth Times: Masonwith his mum Maxine Ahmun and brother Benjamin Ahmun" class"editor-image"Masonwith his mum Maxine Ahmun and brother Benjamin AhmunldquoI have never been a runner - always struggled with it, but started doing short runs during lockdown just for fitness and then started running for charity.In April , during first lockdown, she completed  miles in nine days for Alzheimerrsquos Society and during January of this year raised money for Maggiersquos Charity where she ran  miles throughout the month.ldquoSo, for MAS app, I set up a fundraiser with just giving to raise money. Our aim was to raise pound but we are now exceeding pound, she said.At the end of her run she was met by lots of Masonrsquos family and friends, as well as her own.To donate head tohttps:www.justgiving crowdfunding verity-tucker utm_termQmrWVAgk.ldquoIt was incredible and I am honoured to have been able to do this for them and for the memory of Mason," she added. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: senedd election    need know
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communitySenedd Election  - all you need to know about voting during coronavirus" Senedd Election  - all you need to know about voting during coronavirusBallot box" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTODAYS the day - the Senedd Election is here, and, with coronavirus uncertainty still lingering in everyday le, people may still have some questions about what will happen.Today the people of Wales will vote to decide who their Senedd Members will be for the next five years.There are  MSs in total.The election will also decide who forms the next Welsh Government - responsible for hospitals, schools and transport in Wales.The Welsh Government is formed from the party holding the most seats and is led by the first minister.If a single party wins more than  seats, they are able to form a government. Otherwise a coalition must be attempted.:Who can vote Anyone over the age of  can vote in the Senedd election provided they are:- registered to do so- living in Wales- not legally excluded from votingThis is the first time  and -year-olds have been eligible to vote. What impact that has on the result remains to be seen.How do I vote There are three ways - in person, by post and by proxy - however, the deadlines for latter two options have already passed.Voting at the polling booth with take place until pm today.Polling stations will be kitted out with hand sanitiser and distancing markers to help voters remain safe from coronavirus.Most crucially, voters are being asked to bring their own pen or pencil.Face coverings must also be worn, unless exempt.How does the voting system work Each voter will have two votes - one constituency vote and one regional vote.Youll be represented in the Senedd by five Members. One for your constituency and four for the region of Wales where you live.Constituency vote - this is for the person you want to represent you and your local area. Wales has  constituencies, with each being represented by one MS in the Senedd. Constituency votes are counted in a first past the post system - so the candidate with the most votes is elected.     Regional vote - This is for who you want to represent your region of Wales - South Wales East, South Wales Central, South Wales West Mid and West Wales and North Wales. There are  regional Senedd Members, elected by the additional member system.When will results be announced As with a lot of things this past year, the election has been hit by Covid restrictions.While voting will happen today, counting will not take place the same night as is usually the case on election night.Instead, the votes will be taken to the counting locations and kept secure until morning.They will then be veried - spoiled ballots removed - and counted.Due to Covid restrictions, this will likely take longer than in normal counts, but results are expected within two days of polls closing.Keep an eye on the Argus website for the latest, and results. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: aldi bring back christmas favourite brits prepare celebrate junemas
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAs anticipation builds for lockdown restrictions lting completely on June , Brits are gearing up to enjoy the Christmas we never had on June .With limited celebrations in December amid coronavirus lockdown restrictions research has shown that nearly half of Britsare planning to celebrate lsquoJunemasrsquo with friends and family next month.Itrsquos clear with December lockdown now a distant memory, the thought of Christmas and being reunited with our friends and family has us feeling all sentimental.And to help Brits celebrate the festivities, Aldi is bringing back its popular Specially Selected Mini Mince Pies." alt"Penarth Times: Specially Selected Mini Mince Pies. " class"editor-image"Specially Selected Mini Mince Pies. When asked what festive food they would most like to see back on shelves this Junemas, half of Britslisted mince pies as their quintessential Christmas treat.Web searches for lsquomince piesrsquo also went up by an incredible % in April alone, as the nation prepares to celebrate Christmas this summer.With % of people planning a lockdown-lting party, the most popular celebration is set to be with our closest friends, with over % of those polled looking forward to being reunited with pals theyrsquove missed, closely followed by get-togethers with extended family .Julie Ashfield, Managing Director of Buying at Aldi, commented: ldquoThe first Friday post-lockdown will feel like Christmas, as we all get to meet up with friends and family after months apart.ldquoWe thought letrsquos make it a Junemas to remember by bringing back the nations festive favourite - mince pies - to help celebrate this very special occasion!Aldirsquos Specially Selected Mini Mince Pies will be available for pound. in-store nationwide from st June.Follow Aldi as it gears up for the summer celebrations on #AldiJunemas where shoppers can cast their vote on what other yuletide favourites they would like to see back in store for Junemas. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"Comments are closed on this article. -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: kate promises turn pink dress four year old mila
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityKate chatted on the phone with four-year-old Mila Sneddon, who was pictured for the Hold Still initiative, kissing the kitchen window as her father Scott stood outside.Mila, who is undergoing chemotherapy for leukaemia, was separated from her father in the first lockdown for seven weeks, after he had to go to work and could not risk bringing coronavirus into the family home in Falkirk.The duchess admitted she was ldquonot wearing a princess costume right now when she was quizzed by the youngster on her outfit, but pledged to wear Milarsquos favourite colour when they eventually meet in person.Introducing lsquoShielding Milarsquo the first of a series of telephone calls that The Duchess held with participants from the Hold Still project.https:t.co weQpMajwmdash The Duke and Duchess of CambridgeMay , In a conversation posted on the Cambridgesrsquo new YouTube channel on Thursday, Mila asked Kate: ldquoDo you have a costume The duchess replied: ldquoIrsquom not wearing a princess costume right now, Irsquom afraid Mila. Do you have lots of dressing-up outfits yourself Mila said: ldquoYeah and told the duchess her favourite colour was pink.Kate added: ldquoOK, well I have to make sure I go and try and find myself a pink dress so that hopefully, when one day hopefully, Mila wersquoll get to meet, and then Irsquoll remember to wear my pink dress for you. Would that be nice The image of Mila and her father, taken by her mother Lynda, was entitled Shielding Mila, and was one of  pictures selected for the Hold Still photography initiative, launched by Kate and the National Portrait Gallery in .Coming this Fridayhellip##HoldStill @NPGLondon @coopuk pic VbOpfrZIQmdash The Duke and Duchess of CambridgeMay , People of all ages across the UK were invited to submit a photo which they had taken during lockdown, focusing on three themes ndash helpers and heroes, your new normal and acts of kindness.The call, recorded last autumn, was released to mark the publication of Katersquos new Hold Still photography book on Friday.Kate asked Mila about being apart from her father: ldquoHow come you couldnrsquot see him for so long Mila replied: ldquoBecause he had to look after me because I went for a treatment.The duchess asked: ldquoWas it really hard not seeing him Mila replied it was and told of the poignant moment they were reunited, saying: ldquoWhen he came into the house I was like, so surprised.The calls, which took place last autumn, saw The Duchess speak to a number of the  finalists who shared their experiences of le during the first COVID- lockdown in the UK by submitting an image to Hold Still. #HoldStillmdash The Duke and Duchess of CambridgeMay , The duchess told Mila: ldquoItrsquos a very small age to have a big operation. Were you very brave  You were a very strong girl, werenrsquot you Mila proudly said to Kate: ldquoI know all your kidsrsquo names.The duchess asked hershe could remember them, with the youngster listing Charlotte, then George and finally Louis.The duchess told her how Louis, who has just turned three, has been charging around on his scooter.ldquoLouis has got so big now. Hersquos very quick running around and hersquos on his little scooter as well. Hersquos very quick. I canrsquot keep up with him, Kate said.Mila began the call by saying: ldquoGood morning your royal highness. To which Kate replied: ldquoGood morning. Goodness me, yoursquore so polite Mila.The duchess also spoke to Milarsquos mother Lynda, describing how she and the rest of the judging  felt that the image was ldquosuch a powerful one. vw,vw,px, px"A mural in Manchester of one of the Hold Still photographs showing nurse Melanie Senior ldquoIt tells the story of this particular time and a very personal story to you, so thank you very for much for sharing it, Kate said.Mila is now five and currently in hospital, which Mrs Sneddon described to ITV as a ldquowee bump in the road.The youngster was also separated from her older sister Jodi during the first lockdown.ldquoIt must have been so challenging for all of you during lockdown, being separated, the duchess said to Mrs Sneddon.Mrs Sneddon said lockdown had had the surprise benefit of allowing them a period of time to focus on Milarsquos treatment without interruptions.She added: ldquoWersquove had our ups and downs. Scott and I are so proud of Mila and Jodi, my eldest, through this time and the challenges they have had to overcome..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Kate promises to turn up in pink dress for four-year-old Mila article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: engineers biologists join forces reveal seals evolved swim
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe findings could have potential implications for improving the design of man-made machines such as underwater drones and submersibles.Using cutting-edge engineering and animal behaviour, scientists have explained the origins of efficient swimming in the animals.Seals and sea lions are fast-swimming ocean predators that use their flippers to ldquofly through the water.But not all seals are the same ndash some use their front flippers to swim, while others propel themselves with their back feet.Fur seals and sea lions have wing-like front flippers specialised for swimming, while grey and harbour seals have stubby, clawed paws and swim with their feet.The reason behind these two dferent methods has long been a mystery to biologists, but now a new study led by Australiarsquos Monash University and including scientists from Londonrsquos Natural History Museumhas attempted to understand the evolution of these distinctive styles.Using computer simulations alongside footage of live seals, the team hoped to finally answer this mystery.Dr Travis Park, a researcher from the Natural History Museum who was involved in the study, said: ldquoOne of the key specimens used in this study was a female grey seal that was brought to the Natural History Museum after its remains were found in Margate.ldquoAlong with help from the Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital, who CT-scanned the animal for us, our scientists were able to turn this sad loss into a new understanding of how swimming in seals has evolved.The adult grey seal was found dead in Walpole Bay in Margate in  and was taken to the NHM for study.As well as analysing the animalrsquos limbs for the study, the team looked for parasites and investigated its stomach for a study into marine le ingestion of plastics.During the dissection, the team found a metal object in the sealrsquos head which they believed to be the cause of death. They reported the finding to the RSPCA.     As well as real specimens, researchers used simulations to help understand how dferent seals propel themselves through the water.Lead author David Hocking, of Monash University, teamed up with engineer Dr Shibo Wang, from the universityrsquos department of mechanical and aerospace engineering, to use simulations to show how water flows around seal flippers of dferent shapes.Dr Hocking said: ldquoOur analysis showed that some Antarctic seals, like leopard seals, actually have very streamlined, wing-like forelimbs, despite being from the lsquofoot-propelledrsquo seal family.The discovery shows how wing-like flippers can evolve in seals that already swim with their back feet, providing a pathway for the evolution of forelimb swimming in the fur seals and sea lions.Dr Park added: ldquoWe found that grey seals still use their paws to hold their prey when processing it, but other seals like leopard seals have forgone this ability to maximise their swimming speed and agility, being able to capture more mobile prey.Researchers said that as well as explaining the origin of seals, this study may also improve human design.Dr Hocking said: ldquoSeals have had millions of years to perfect their swimming, and they can teach us a thing or two about underwater grace and elegance.ldquoLearning from them may help us to improve the design of human-built machines like underwater drones and submersibles, increasing their speed, manoeuvrability or energy efficiency.rsquondash The study is published in Current Biology.Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pop up polling station set car boot keyholder oversleeps
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityPolls were due to open at am on Thursday at the Oxford Centre for Mission Studies, however voters arrived to find the doors locked.Oxford City Council confirmed the keyholder had overslept, and the presiding officer used their car as a makesht polling station as is ldquostandard procedure.A spokesman said everyone waiting had been able to vote, and the building was open within  minutes.The church warden has overslept apparently so just cast my vote in a car. #LocalElections pic AstsGWlYmdash Toby PorterMay , Voter Toby Porter said he was one of around a dozen people who cast their ballots in the pop-up station.ldquoWe found it funny. Everyone was enjoying the novelty, he told the PA news agency.A council spokesman said: ldquoThe keyholder overslept and for a short time at am electors were voting using the POrsquoscar.ldquoThis is standard procedure when a station building isnrsquot open on time and part of the training we give them.ldquoThe key is that ballot papers are ready to be issued at am, wherever that may be. The building was open within  minutes. vw,vw,px, px"Laura Lock, deputy chief executive of the Association of Electoral Administrators, said some polling stations in cars are seen at each election.ldquoAll polling station staff are trained on how to set up temporary polling stations for cases just like this, she said.ldquoUnfortunately we do find key holders oversleeping, so every election we see a handful of polling stations in cars until access to the building can be sorted..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Pop-up polling station set up in car boot after keyholder oversleeps article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: council goes behind closed doors
story: Application for eight new dwellings   Lodge criticises policing of band parade celebrating NI centenaryNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPoliticsCouncil goes behind closed doorsArmagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council has taken the decision to conduct the majority of its businesses behind closed doors in May.By The NewsroomWednesday, th May , : pm  "       "  With the exception of its planning committee, the rest of Council’s committees will not meet this month.Instead, four working groups – one for each committee, made up of the members of each committee, will meet behind closed doors to discuss Council’s business.Any decision reached at these working groups will require unanimous support before the outcomes are adopted by Council with Council’s Chief Executive, Roger Wilson, signing off on them through powers given to him under delegated authority.Roger Wilson, Chief Executive, Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council.When asked why the decision was taken to conduct business in this fashion, a Council spokesperson said it was a result of the change in legislation regarding virtual meetings.The regulations allowing for meetings to take place virtually came into effect on May , , but are due to expire on May  of this year.The Department for Communities has confirmed that new regulations will not be in place for a seamless continuation of remote meetings but has advised the regulations should be in place in early June.At least one other Council is continuing with its programme of virtual committee meetings, streamed live to the public, with the decisions reached implemented by the Chief Executive under delegated authority.With this in mind, it is unclear why Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council has decided that stopping the general public from viewing these meetings is the best option.Attempting to explain that situation, a Council spokesperson said: “This decisionwas taken due to the change in legislation regarding virtual meetings.“In the absence of formal committees for the month of May , it has been approved by Council that it will operatea delegated authority approach for the implementationof decisions.“However, council officers will continue to brief elected members on key issues and seek their direction through a series of working groups.“As Council will operate under delegated authority for this period, the livestreaming of meetings will not take place.”When asked to explain why, given the ongoing COVID- pandemic and the planned roll out of the vaccine, the time limited legislation permitting the holding of virtual council meetings was allowed to expire, a spokesperson for the Department for Communities offered little in the way of explanation.“The action needed to extend this legislation is currently being progressed,” said the DfC spokesperson.Editor’s message:Thank you for reading this article. title: free bulky waste collection to continue
story: Application for eight new dwellings   Lodge criticises policing of band parade celebrating NI centenaryNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPoliticsFree bulky waste collection to continueArmagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council is to extend a pilot scheme that saw it offer a bulky waste collection service for free for a further  months.By The NewsroomWednesday, th May , : pm  "       "  Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council is to extend a pilot scheme that saw it offer a bulky waste collection service for free for a further  months.The recommendation to do so was unanimously agreed upon by elected representatives at a behind closed doors meeting of Council’s environmental services working group on Tuesday, May .Despite all members present reaching a unanimous agreement on this matter, it will require rubber stamping by the organisation’s ChiefExecutive, Roger Wilson, via his powers of delegated authority, although it is anticipated this will be a formality.Council had offered a bulky waste collection service for free in the - financial year.A total of , bulky waste collections were carried out in the   financial year. Had these been paid for, as they would have been in the   financial year, this could have generated £, for Council.Speaking at March’s meeting of Council’s environmental services committee, Council’s head of environmental services, Barry Patience, accepted  was not a “normal year” for data on the use of the service to be collected.Although he did note that prior to the introduction of free bulky waste collections, the service had been generating £-, in revenue for Council.SDLP Councillor Ciaran Toman made a proposal at that meeting for officers to bring a report back to the committee on the possibility of an extension of the fee free bulky waste collection service.The proposal was seconded by his party colleague, Councillor Thomas Larkham.Speaking to the Local Democracy Reporting Service this week, Cllr Toman welcomed the working group’s ability to speak with one voice on this matter.“It has been a tough year for everyone,” said Cllr Toman. “While Council carried out , bulky waste collections over the past year, the recorded fly-tipping incidents jumped from  in   to  in  .“This suggests some form of direct correlation between the closing of our recycling centres and the postponed bulky waste collections which were affected by the pandemic.“I very much see bulky waste collections as an essential service in Council’s efforts to tackle fly-tipping and keeping our streets and countryside clean.“I am pleased there was unanimous agreement to maintain the system as it is, fee-free and review it again in a further  months.”Editor’s message:Thank you for reading this article. We’re more reliant on your support than ever as the sht in consumer habits brought about by Coronavirus impacts our advertisers.Please consider purchasing a copy of the paper.
